fields.description: The Marginalia of the Daily Journals from 1683 until 1708 are presented here. Digitizing the Marginalia is a tremendous work and is still ongoing. The Daily Journals of 1625 until 1682, and from 1709 until 1806 are worked on and the Marginalia are expected to be added here in 2014.

fields.description: The Harta Karun collection is a growing collection of archival sources important to acquiring  knowledge and understanding of the Early-Modern history of the Indonesian Archipelago, and of the Asian-European encounter. Historians and archivists are working together at ANRI to uncover these treasures.
fields.title: Harta Karun
fields.description_id: Harta Karun merupakan koleksi sumber-sumber arsip yang terus bertumbuh-kembang dan bernilai penting bagi mereka yang ingin memperoleh pengetahuan serta pemahaman tentang sejarah Kepulauan Indonesia di masa Awal-Modern, dan juga tentang perjumpaan Asia dengan Eropa. Para sejarawan dan arsiparis bekerja sama di ANRI untuk mengungkap harta karun yang masih terpendam ini.
fields.description_en: The Harta Karun collection is a growing collection of archival sources important to acquiring  knowledge and understanding of the Early-Modern history of the Indonesian Archipelago, and of the Asian-European encounter. Historians and archivists are working together at ANRI to uncover these treasures.
fields.content:
Harta Karun means ”Hidden Treasures”. This collection is based on a wealth of so far largely unused primary sources in the ANRI VOC archives. Archivists and international historians specialized in the use of VOC archives are selecting, preparing and publishing these documents with the help of skilled and experienced translators.

One of the main principles of selection is to unravel the local and regional history of pre-colonial and early colonial Nusantara. Nusantara is the ancient name for the Indonesian Archipelago, dating from the time of the great kingdoms of Srivijaya and Majapahit. The selection also includes documents about Asian maritime states and settlements across the whole of the Indian Ocean and the China Seas. Given thediverse nature of the archives, plenty of information is still waiting to be collected on various aspects of the Asian-European encounter.

The documents selected in this digital collection can help to unravel the history of Indonesia and the Asian-European encounter bu,t before this can be done, several methodological complications must be overcome. First, the relevant information from documents originating from officials of a European merchant company, private tradesmen or burghers residing in Dutch colonial territory must be filtered. The task of professional historians is to deal with the often one-sided, Eurocentric perspective of such documents. Some papers are swarm with biased opinions of and negative, sometimes disturbing, ideas about Asian peoples. Awareness of this limitation makes it possible to collect the information objectively.

Secondly, importantly in the hitherto unresearched series in ANRI are hidden thousands of letters penned by Asian writers. Historians and linguists will have to develop methodologies to analyse the documents produced by Asian writers, who range from sultans, local rulers and kings to tradesmen and citizens. To arrive at a correct analysis is a challenge. Dutch clerks in Batavia Castle translated all these letters, originally written in Malay, Javanese, Sundanese, Timorese , Madurese et cetera immediately after receipt of the original. These often beautifully decorated missives embellished with gold were conveyed to the VOC headquarters with great pump and circumstance and were presented to the Governor-General on a silver salver covered by a piece of yellow silk to a salute of cannon. The letter was first read aloud in the indigenous language and then translated into Dutch. Most of these original letters have succumbed to the teeth of time and the fate of the originals is unknown. The Daily Journals of Batavia Castle contain a rich collection of translated documents from Asian letter-writers. The Appendices to the Resolution Books actually still do contain some original Asian letters, but the most splendid gold missives have disappeared.

The way to give access to the documents in antiquated Dutch and often difficult to decipher, is to look at the wider region of Island Southeast Asia from new perspectives. Much of the older historiography has already been decolonized, but historiography can still be improved by uncovering new facts, events and developments, and by using a local or regional perspective in the analysis.

The first aim of the Harta Karun collection is to recover facts which help to reconstruct maritime, political, socio-economic and religious developments in the Archipelago and put it in its strategic Asian context, in particular in its relationship to China and India.

The ‘Harta Karun’ collection of selected documents also offers many documents on Asian history in general, stretching from Japan to Arabia, fulfilling the second aim of the collection. This second section is arranged geographically. It should be remembered that the most important documents about the wider Asian region are in The Hague. The National Archives in The Hague keeps the copybooks of the so called ‘Ingekomen Indiase brievenboecken’ (the incoming Asian letter-books) which were forwarded from Batavia Castle to the Chambers of the VOC in the Dutch Republic. Apart from some scattered fragments, many volumes from the original series of these letter-books copied at the General Secretariat in Batavia Castle have not survived in Jakarta, largely on account of the lack of interest in the colonial period.

The third aim of the collection of ‘Harta Karun’ documents is to collect information related to Asian-European interactions, trading activities, co-operations and clashes, and all subjects related to early colonial expansion in the context of Global History.

The fourth aim is to rediscover the history of the biggest colonial city in Asia: Batavia. Ruled with a firm hand by various local city institutions, Batavia was always a city with a population which was at least 90  per cent Asian. The challenge is to reconstruct the social and economic lives of the thousands of individuals, dozens of ethnic groups and nationalities who all flocked together in this complex urban environment in the hope of finding a better life. This website will contribute to the rediscovery of Batavia as a predominantly Asian-Indonesian city.
fields.content_id:
Koleksi “harta karun yang terpendam” ini bertumpu pada sumber-sumber primer yang tersimpan dalam arsip VOC di ANRI; selama ini sumber-sumber yang sangat berharga itu belum banyak dimanfaatkan. Para arsiparis dan sejarawan mancanegara yang sudah mahir memanfaatkan arsip VOC, kini memilah, menyiapkan serta menerbitkan sejumlah dokumen tersebut dibantu oleh para penerjemah yang handal dan berpengalaman.

Salah satu asas utama dalam melakukan seleksi adalah mengungkap sejarah lokal dan regional Nusantara, di masa pra-kolonial dan awal kolonial. “Nusantara” merupakan nama masa lalu bagi Kepulauan Indonesia; nama yang disandang pada masa ketika kerajaan-kerajaan besar seperti Sriwijaya dan Majapahit masih berjaya. Yang juga diseleksi adalah dokumen-dokumen yang berhubungan dengan negara serta permukiman maritim Asia yang terbentang di seantero Samudra Hindia dan Laut Cina. Mengingat keaneka-ragaman arsip bersangkutan, maka dapat dipastikan bahwa sangat banyak informasi yang masih menunggu untuk digali, khususnya terkait sejumlah aspek yang melekat pada perjumpaan Asia dengan Eropa.

Dokumen-dokumen yang diseleksi dalam koleksi digital ini memang dapat membantu menyingkap sejarah Indonesia dan perjumpaan Asia-Eropa namun, sebelum itu, sejumlah masalah metodologi masih harus diselesaikan terlebih dahulu. Pertama, informasi berguna yang terdapat dalam dokumen-dokumen yang dibuat oleh sebuah perusahaan dagang, para pedagang swasta atau warga yang tinggal di kawasan jajahan Belanda perlu disaring terlebih dahulu. Tugas para sejarawan profesional adalah bagaimana menyikapi dokumen-dokumen tersebut yang seringkali berat sebelah dan Eropa-sentris. Sebagian dari arsip itu sarat dengan pandangan yang bias dan negatip, terkadang merisaukan, terkait orang-orang Asia. Dengan menyadari keterbatasan tersebut, maka dapat dilakukan penggalian informasi secara obyektip.

Kedua, ribuan surat yang ratusan tahun lalu ditulis oleh orang-orang Asia masih terpendam dalam arsip-arsip di ANRI dan belum pernah ditelusur. Para sejarawan dan ahli bahasa perlu mengembangkan serangkaian metodologi untuk menganalisis dokumen-dokumen tersebut yang diciptakan para penulis Asia dari berbagai ragam latar belakang: mulai dari sultan, penguasa dan raja setempat hingga pedagang dan warga biasa. Membuat sebuah analisa yang akurat memanglah merupakan tantangan. Ketika itu, para kerani Belanda di Kastel Batavia dengan tekun menerjemahkan semua surat yang aslinya ditulis dalam bahasa Melayu, Jawa, Sunda, Timor, Madura dan lain sebagainya begitu surat diterima. Surat-surat tersebut seringkali dihiasi dengn aksara dan gambar tinta emas dan dihantar ke kantor pusat VOC disertai upacara megah dan diperembahkan kepada Gubernur Jenderal di atas talam perak bertilam kain sutera berwarna kuning ke-emasan diirngi dentuman meriam kehormatan. Mula pertama, surat dibacakan dengan lantang dalam bahasa aslinya dan kemudian dialih-bahasakan dalam bahasa Belanda. Sebagian besar surat asli tersebut sudah punah dimakan waktu dan nasibnya kini tidak diketahui. Catatan Harian Kastel Batavia berisi koleksi terjemahan berharga itu yang merupakan buah pena para penulis surat berbangsa Asia. Beberapa dari surat asli tersebut memang masih ditemukan dalam lampiran pada Buku-buku Resolusi, namun sebagian besar naskah indah bertinta emas itu kini lenyap sudah.

Agar dapat memahami dokumen-dokumen yang ditulis dalam bahasa Belanda kuno serta seringkali sukar dibaca dan diartikan itu, kiranya kita perlu meneliti kawasan Kepulauan Asia Tenggara dari sudut pandang yang baru. Sebagian besar dari historiografi lama itu kini sudah terbebaskan dari penjajahan, namun sejarah kawasan itu masih dapat ditata dengan lebih sempurna dengan mengunkap serangkaian fakta, kejadian dan perkembangan baru dan membuat analisis dari sudut pandang lokal atau regional. 

Tujuan pertama koleksi Harta Karun ini adalah untuk menemukan kembali sejumlah fakta yang dapat membantu mereka-ulang perkembangan yang telah berlangsung di Kepulauan tersebut yang terkait dengan bidang maritim, politik, sosial-ekonomi dan agama; serta selanjutnya menempatkannya dalam tataran strategis Asia, khususnya dalam hubungannya dengan Cina dan India.

Koleksi terpilih dalam ‘Harta Karun’ ini juga mempersembahkan banyak dokumen yang bercerita tentang sejarah Asia secara umum, terkait kawasan yang terbentang mulai dari Jepang hingga Arab, dan dengan demikian menghantar kepada tujuan kedua koleksi ini. Untuk itu, bagian kedua disusun secara geografis. Perlu dimaklum bahwa sebagian terbesar dari dokumen-dokumen penting terkait kawasan Asia yang lebih luas kini tersimpan di kota The Hague, Negeri Belanda. Dalam khazanah Arsip Nasional di kota itu  tersimpan sejumlah besar salinan dari apa yang dikenal sebagai Buku Surat-surat Masuk Asia (‘Ingekomen Indiase brievenboeken’); buku-buku salinan itu telah diteruskan dari Kastel Batavia kepada Kamar-kamar Dagang VOC di Republik Belanda ketika itu. Banyak jilid dari buku yang berisi  surat-surat asli tersebut dan telah ditulis ulang di Sekretariat Jenderal di Kastel Batavia dan tersimpan di Jakarta, kini sudah punah terutama akibat kurang diperhatikan selama waktu penjajahan.

Tujuan ketiga koleksi dokumen ‘Harta Karun’ ini adalah menghimpun informasi terkait antar hubungan Asia-Eropa, kegiatan perdagangan, kerjasama dan pertentangan, dan semua subyek yang berhubungan dengan ekspansi di awal masa penjajahan dan menempatkannya dalam konteks Sejarah Global.

Tujuan ke-empat adalah untuk menemukan kembali sejarah kota jajahan terbesar di Asia: Batavia. Di masa itu, kota tersebut diperintah secara tegas melalui berbagai lembaga kota dan sejak dahulu merupakan permukiman 90 persen pendudukya adalah orang Asia. Tantangannya kini adalah, bagaimana mereka-ulang tata kehidupan ribuan orang, lusinan kelompok etnis dan bangsa yang semuanya berduyun-duyun berdatangan ke kawasan kota yang sarat kerumitan itu, demi mencari kehidupan yang lebih baik. Situs ini diharapkan dapat memberikan sumbang saran untuk menemukan kembali wajah Batavia sebagai sebuah kota yang terutama dihuni penduduk Asia-Indonesia.

fields.description: This section gives direct access to the scans of the primary sources. This is started in 2013 and will lead in time to a growing number of scanned archival series. The first series to be presented here is the Daily Journals.
fields.title: Digital Archive Collections
fields.description_en: This section gives direct access to the scans of the primary sources. This is started in 2013 and will lead in time to a growing number of scanned archival series. The first series to be presented here is the Daily Journals.
fields.content: The first archival series that are now scanned were laminated and rebound during a restoration project in 1978 – 1981, initiated by the former Director of ANRI, Soemartini. She took the right decision to restore the series most important to historians first.
fields.content_id: Berkas-berkas arsip pertama yang sudah dipindai, telah dilaminasikan dan dijilid kembali dalam suatu proyek restorasi di tahun 1978-1979, yang diprakarsai oleh mantan Direktur ANRI, Soemartini (alm). Beliau telah mengambil keputusan benar dengan melestarikan terlebih dahulu seri-seri yang paling penting untuk para sejarawan.
fields.content_en: The first archival series that are now scanned were laminated and rebound during a restoration project in 1978 – 1981, initiated by the former Director of ANRI, Soemartini. She took the right decision to restore the series most important to historians first.

fields.description: The General Resolution Books of the High Government were created under the supervision of the Secretary General in the Castle of Batavia.
fields.title: Resolution Books
fields.description_id: Buku-buku Surat Keputusan Umum dari Pemerintah Agung juga dibuat di bawah pengawasan Sekretaris Jenderal di Kastil Batavia.
fields.description_en: The General Resolution Books of the High Government were created under the supervision of the Secretary General in the Castle of Batavia.
fields.content:
The 330 volumes of the General Resolution Books contain the final version of the minutes of the meetings of the High Government 1613 – 1810. The General Affairs Books (Besogneboeken, 1743 – 1794) deal with decisions about the outer establishments in Asia. Whereas the Daily Journals of Batavia decreased in importance and size in the second half of the 18th century, the General Resolution Books expanded beyond the reading capacity of any single person.

Like the Daily Journals of Batavia, the Resolution Books also have marginalia on the folio pages and marginalia lists in the front of any particular volume. Entering all the marginalia lists of the General Resolutions Books would be an enormous task. Together, all lists add up to c. 13,500 folio pages of hand-written texts.

 

The problem of how to access such long lists of marginalia is an old one. To keep track of the High Government’s main decisions, in the early 18th century the Secretary General and his clerks began to select the principal decisions from the marginalia lists. They did so with the help of a list of more then 200 subjects or Realia. First they wrote their selection in a chronological list and then added subjects in the margins. The second step was to reproduce the list of selected marginalia in alphabetical order. The clerks produced annual Realia or subject indexes. It was a standard procedure to reformulate the marginalia as the clerks read through the marginalia lists. They always compared these texts with the original resolution text and then reformulated them. Every 3.5 or even every 10 years, the annual alphabetically organized Realia were compiled into a periodical Realia book. At the beginning of the 19th century, the archives of Batavia Castle contained more than 40 such periodical Realia books (both original and copies). These Realia books were frequently consulted in the 19th century and deteriorated over time. Between 1882 and 1886, the periodical Realia books were typed out and published in three volumes by the Batavian Society for Arts and Sciences.

The Realia published in the 19th century have been a useful tool for historians for 125 years, but obviously they have their limitations. The selection of subjects is Company-centric, it is a contemporary 18th-century choice compounded by many errors in transcription. It only covers around 10 % of the marginalia registers in the Resolution and Besogne  Books. Despite these limitations, the Realia have been digitized as a research tool. More marginalia lists from the General Resolution Books will be entered into the database in the course of the programme.
fields.content_id:
Ke-330 jilid Buku Surat-surat Keputusan Umum memuat versi akhir dari risalah pertemuan Pemerintah Agung di tahun 1613-1810. Buku Urusan Umum (Besogneboeken, 1743-1794) memuat keputusan-keputusan tentang pendirian kantor-kantor luar di Asia. Sementara nilai penting serta besaran Catatan Harian Batavia mulai berkurang di paruh kedua abad ke-18, Buku-Buku Surat Keputusan justru berkembang sedemikian besar sehingga menjadi sesuatu yang di luar kemampuan membaca seseorang.

Seperti halnya Catatan Harian Batavia, maka Buku-buku Surat Keputusan juga memiliki marginalia di halaman-halaman folionya serta daftar marginalia di bagian depan setiap jilid. Mencatat semua daftar marginalia dari Buku-buku Keputusan Umum merupakan tugas yang sangat besar. Kesemua daftar itu terdiri dari sekitar 13.500 halaman folio yang berisi catatan dalam tulisan tangan.

Persoalan seputar bagaimana mengakses daftar-daftar marginalia yang begitu panjang merupakan persoalan lama. Untuk merunut keputusan-keputusan umum Pemerintah Agung maka di awal abad ke-18, Sekretaris Jenderal bersama para keraninya mulai menyeleksi keputusan-keputusan pokok dari daftar marginalia. Mereka bekerja dengan bantuan sebuah daftar yang berisi 200 pokok permasalahan atau Realia. Mula pertama, mereka mencatat secara kronologis apa yang mereka seleksi ke dalam sebuah, kemudian mereka menambahkan subyek atau masalah di tepi halaman. Langkah kedua adalah menulis ulang daftar dari marginalia yang sudah diseleksi dan menyusunnya secara abjad. Para kerani menghasilkan Realia atau indeks masalah tahunan. Itu merupakan prosedur standar untuk merumus-ulang sementara para kerani membaca daftar marginalia. Mereka selalu membandingkan teks tersebut dengan teks surat keputusan asli lalu kemudian merumuskannya kembali. Setiap 3, 5 atau 10 tahun Realia yang diurut per abjad dihimpun menjadi Buku Realia secara berkala. Di awal abad ke-19, dalam arsip Kastil Batavia terdapat lebih dari 40 Buku Realia demikian (baik yang asli maupun salinannya). Buku-buku Realia tersebut sering dipakai sebagai rujukan di abad ke-19 dan sebab itu menjadi rusak sejalan dengan bergulirnya waktu. Antara 1882 dan 1886, buku-buku Realia berkala itu diketik kembali dan diterbitkan dalam tiga jilid oleh Batavian Society for Arts and Sciences

Realia yang diterbitkan dalam abad ke-19 sudah berfungsi sebagai alat berguna untuk para sejarawan selama 125 tahun, namun nampaknya, ada juga keterbatasannya. Pemilihan subyek-subyek didasarkan pada kepentingan Kumpeni serta merupakan pilihan sesuai kepentingan abad ke-18 dan selain itu ada banyak kesalahan dalam penulisan kembali. Padahal hanya terkait sekitar 10% dari daftar-daftar marginalia yang ada di Buku-buku Keputusan dan Buku Besogne. Kendati keterbatasan tersebut, Realia  sudah didigitalisasikan sebagai piranti riset. Daftar-daftar Marginalia dari Buku Keputusan Umum akan dimasukkan ke dalam situs selama berjalannya proyek ini.
fields.content_en:
The 330 volumes of the General Resolution Books contain the final version of the minutes of the meetings of the High Government 1613 – 1810. The General Affairs Books (Besogneboeken, 1743 – 1794) deal with decisions about the outer establishments in Asia. Whereas the Daily Journals of Batavia decreased in importance and size in the second half of the 18th century, the General Resolution Books expanded beyond the reading capacity of any single person.

Like the Daily Journals of Batavia, the Resolution Books also have marginalia on the folio pages and marginalia lists in the front of any particular volume. Entering all the marginalia lists of the General Resolutions Books would be an enormous task. Together, all lists add up to c. 13,500 folio pages of hand-written texts.

 

The problem of how to access such long lists of marginalia is an old one. To keep track of the High Government’s main decisions, in the early 18th century the Secretary General and his clerks began to select the principal decisions from the marginalia lists. They did so with the help of a list of more then 200 subjects or Realia. First they wrote their selection in a chronological list and then added subjects in the margins. The second step was to reproduce the list of selected marginalia in alphabetical order. The clerks produced annual Realia or subject indexes. It was a standard procedure to reformulate the marginalia as the clerks read through the marginalia lists. They always compared these texts with the original resolution text and then reformulated them. Every 3.5 or even every 10 years, the annual alphabetically organized Realia were compiled into a periodical Realia book. At the beginning of the 19th century, the archives of Batavia Castle contained more than 40 such periodical Realia books (both original and copies). These Realia books were frequently consulted in the 19th century and deteriorated over time. Between 1882 and 1886, the periodical Realia books were typed out and published in three volumes by the Batavian Society for Arts and Sciences.

The Realia published in the 19th century have been a useful tool for historians for 125 years, but obviously they have their limitations. The selection of subjects is Company-centric, it is a contemporary 18th-century choice compounded by many errors in transcription. It only covers around 10 % of the marginalia registers in the Resolution and Besogne  Books. Despite these limitations, the Realia have been digitized as a research tool. More marginalia lists from the General Resolution Books will be entered into the database in the course of the programme.

fields.description: Various archival series of the VOC archives in Jakarta have been published with the co-operation of the former ‘Landsarchief van Batavia’ (the predecessor of ANRI housed in the 18th-century house on the estate of Councillor of Asia Reinier de Klerck).
fields.title: Retro Books
fields.description_id: Sejumlah seri arsip VOC di Batavia/Jakarta telah diterbitkan bekerjasama dengan Arsip Negara Batavia (pendahulu ANRI yang berkantor di rumah yang dibangun dalam abad ke-18 di lahan anggota Dewan Asia, Reinier de Klerck).
fields.description_en: Various archival series of the VOC archives in Jakarta have been published with the co-operation of the former ‘Landsarchief van Batavia’ (the predecessor of ANRI housed in the 18th-century house on the estate of Councillor of Asia Reinier de Klerck).
fields.content:
All such published archival series (the originals still kept by ANRI) are included in this section of Retro Books: the Nederlandsch-Indisch Plakaatboek, (Dutch-Indies Placards or Law Books), the Daghregisters van Batavia (Daily Journals of Batavia, 1624 – 1682), the Corpus Diplomaticum Neerlando-Indicum (Contracts between the VOC and Asian kings and rulers), F. de Haan’s Priangan and the Bouwstoffen voor de geschiedenis der Protestantsche kerk in Nederlandsch-Indië (the minutes of the meetings of the Batavian church council, 1621 – 1684).

The 1882 inventory of the VOC archives published by Mr. J.A. van der Chijs has also been included.

These retro books should be consulted in close conjunction with the VOC retro books published digitally by the Huygens ING Institute (see http://www.historici.nl/retro).
fields.content_id:
Semua seri arsip yang diterbitkan tersebut (aslinya tetap disimpan di ANRI) dimasukkan ke dalam bagian Buku-buku Retro: Nederlandsch-Indisch Plakaatboek (Buku Plakat Hindia Belanda atau Buku-buku Peraturan), Daghregisters van Batavia (Catatan Harian Batavia, 1624-1682), Corpus Diplomaticum Neerlando-Indicum (Surat-surat perjanjian/kontrak antara VOC dengan para raja dan penguasa Asia), Priangan karangan F. de Haan serta Boustoffen voor de geschiedenis der Protestantsche kerk in Nederlandsch-Indie (risalah rapat/pertemuan dewan gereja Batavia, 1621-1684).

Daftar inventaris 1882 arsip VOC yang diterbitkan oleh Mr. J.A. van der Chijs juga dimasukkan.

Buku-buku retro ini perlu dirujuk bersama dengan buku-buku retro VOC yang diterbitkan dalam bentuk digital oleh Huygens ING Institute (http://www.historici.nl/retro).

fields.description: The enormous amount of Realia entries can be searched in full text by entering one or more keywords. As each Realia entry has a subject, this also can be used as a selection criteria. To further decrease the number of results, it is possible to set a time frame. Selection can lead to one or more results. Each result can be clicked on, invoking the browse page on the exact position in the original published Realia.
fields.title: Search Realia
fields.description_en: The enormous amount of Realia entries can be searched in full text by entering one or more keywords. fields.description: The Daily Journals of Batavia are an imporant historical source that contain information about a great variety of subjects. Because of its sheer size of 165 volumes and a time span of almost two hundred years this archival series can only be accessed with a detailed secondary entry. More then 90,000 searchable marginalia entries provide access to the Daily Journals.
fields.title: Marginalia to the Daily Journals
fields.description_en: The Daily Journals of Batavia are an imporant historical source that contain information about a great variety of subjects. Because of its sheer size of 165 volumes and a time span of almost two hundred years this archival series can only be accessed with a detailed secondary entry. More then 90,000 searchable marginalia entries provide access to the Daily Journals.
fields.content:
Every folio page has short text summaries written in the margins of the text. These short texts are called ‘marginalia’. At the end of a particular year, a clerk copied all the marginalia from every page. He listed them chronologically and added this marginalia list to the front pages of a volume for that year before it was bound. 

All the marginalia lists from the Daily Journals have been entered into a database. The entry of all marginalia into a database gives researchers a detailed reference to almost every folio page of the Daily Journals.

Mona Lohanda and Hendrik E. Niemeijer have transcribed, collated and partly annotated all the marginalia from all the volumes of the Daily Journals. The transcribed marginalia have only been collated (compared with the originals and corrected where necessary) once and some transcription errors might still occur. The marginalia have been transcribed from the individual folio pages. If pages are difficult to read because of browning or ink corrosion, parts of the marginalia lists at the beginning of a volume have been transcribed. In the case of personal or ship’s names, the text itself has been consulted. First names have been added to the family names. The digital marginalia might also contain some additional words from the text if the text of a marginalium did not make sense or had been wrongly formulated.

All incoming and outgoing letters in the period 1683-1694 mentioned in the marginalia are dated in notes. The dates of letters up to 1694 have been collected from the text. The eighteenth-century Daily Journals not give the dates of invidual letters. The letter dates and other comments have been placed in notes in square brackets [...] and are explained with a mouse-over. The letters mentioned in the Daily Journals are directly related to the TANAP Database of VOC Documents. 

Ship’s names are presented in a different column. This list has been taken directly from the marginalia and invariably there are many spelling variants; the ship’s names are standardized in the indexes of ship’s names in the Generale Missiven.

Continue to browse the Marginalia >>

The Marginalia to be quoted as: 
Mona Lohanda and Hendrik E. Niemeijer, Marginalia to the Daily Journals of Batavia Castle (1659-1799).
A digitized contemporary chronological entry to archives of the Dutch East India Company (VOC).
(Jakarta, Arsip Nasional Republik Indonesia / The Corts Foundation, 2013)

fields.description:
The paper remnants of the Dutch East India Company (VOC) operating in Asian waters are scattered in the national archives of Indonesia, the Netherlands, Sri Lanka, South Africa and India.
On March 9th 2004 the archives of the VOC, the Dutch United East India Company (1602 – 1800) were included in the UNESCO Memory of the World Register.
fields.title: Archive
fields.description_id:
Jejak-jejak Serikat Perusahaan Hindia Timur Belanda (Kumpeni) ini kertas, yang berkiprah di lautan Asia, tercecer di sejumlah tempat penyimpanan arsip nasional di Indonesia, Belanda, Sri Lanka, Afrika Selatan dan India.
Pada tanggal 9 Maret 2004, arsip VOC, Serikat Perusahaan Hindia Timur Belanda (Kumpeni) – 1602-1800 dimasukkan dalam Memory of the World Register dari UNESCO.
fields.description_en:
The paper remnants of the Dutch East India Company (VOC) operating in Asian waters are scattered in the national archives of Indonesia, the Netherlands, Sri Lanka, South Africa and India.
On March 9th 2004 the archives of the VOC, the Dutch United East India Company (1602 – 1800) were included in the UNESCO Memory of the World Register.
fields.content:
In many countries with which the VOC was once an active trading partner, Japan, Siam (Thailand), Persia (Iran), Tonkin (Vietnam), Formosa (Taiwan) and a number of other places, no archives have survived. The most voluminous collections spanning 2,500 metres is in the Arsip Nasional Republik Indonesia.

A special archive guide gives an overview of the various (sub-) collections. The most voluminous are the archives of the Governor-General and Councillors of Asia (the High Government) and of the local public and private institutions in Batavia.

The chief concern of the High Government were the internal Company affairs in all such matters as the general management of trade, personnel and financial affairs, shipping and logistics. The High Government also dealt with all political and diplomatic matters, the administration of justice and the correspondence with other VOC factories in Asia and the VOC Chambers and its Board (theHeren XVII, Gentlemen Seventeen, the Directors on the VOC Board) in the Dutch Republic. Before 1743, all matters to do with the regional establishments of the Company were included in to the General Resolution Books. After 1743, such matters were recorded in a separate yearbook, giving birth to a separate series: the General (Foreign) Affairs Books (Net-Generale Besogneboeken).
fields.content_id:
Di banyak negara yang pernah menjadi mitra dagang aktip VOC seperti Jepang, Siam (Thailand), Persia (Iran), Tonkin (Vietnam), Formosa (Taiwan) dan sejumlah tempat lain, tidak ditemukan lagi arsip tersebut. Koleksi paling banyak, yaitu 2.500 meter lari, terdapat di Arsip Nasional Republik Indonesia (ANRI). 

Sebuah petunjuk arsip khusus memberi pandangan umum tentang berbagai sub-koleksi. Yang paling banyak adalah arsip Gubernur Jenderal dan Dewan Penasehat Asia (Pemerintah Agung) serta lembaga publik dan swasta di Batavia.

Bidang perhatian utama Pemerintah Agung adalah urusan-urusan internal Kumpeni seperti yang menyangkut pengelolaan umum perdagangan, urusan kepegawaian dan keuangan, perkapalan dan logistik. Pemerintah Agung juga mengurusi masalah 
politik dan diplomatik, administrasi pengadilan dan surat-menyurat dengan kantor-kantor VOC lainnya di Asia dan Badan VOC serta Dewan VOC (Heren XVII , yang merupakan Dewan direktur VOC) di Republik Belanda. Sebelum 1743, semua urusan terkait pendirian kantor Kumpeni di daerah juga dimasukan ke dalam Buku Surat Keputusan Umum. Sesudah 1743, urusan demikian dicatat dalam sebuah buku tahunan terpisah, sehingga terbitlah Buku-buku Urusan Umum (Luar Negeri) – Net-Generale Besogneboeken

fields.description: All subjects that are mentioned in the three Realia publications are presented here. The subjects are grouped by their first letter and the number of Realia entries are counted. Each individual page per letter has the entries that start with that letter and each individual entry is also counted. Choosing a particular subject will start the Search Realia page and will invoke the selection immediately.
fields.title: Realia Subjects
fields.description_en: All subjects that are mentioned in the three Realia publications are presented here. The subjects are grouped by their first letter and the number of Realia entries are counted. Each individual page per letter has the entries that start with that letter and each individual entry is also counted. Choosing a particular subject will start the Search Realia page and will invoke the selection immediately.

fields.description: Around 47,500 entries give access to more then 211,000 folia pages of Resolutions of the meetings of the Supreme Government of the VOC in Asia. These records were once kept in the Secretary General’s office in Batavia Castle. The Realia are a contemporary (eighteenth-century) repertorium (or subject directory) of more than 2,000 subjects including 47,500 references to government deliberations or decisions.
fields.title: Realia to the Resolutions and Besognes
fields.title_en: Realia to the Resolutions and Besognes
fields.description_en: Around 47,500 entries give access to more then 211,000 folia pages of Resolutions of the meetings of the Supreme Government of the VOC in Asia. These records were once kept in the Secretary General’s office in Batavia Castle. The Realia are a contemporary (eighteenth-century) repertorium (or subject directory) of more than 2,000 subjects including 47,500 references to government deliberations or decisions.
fields.content:
From 1882-1886 the Bataviaasch Genootschap van Kunsten en Wetenschappen (Batavian Society of Arts and Sciences) published three volumes of this subject directory to the most important series of the VOC Headquarters in Asia: the General Resolutions of the Governors-General and Councils of Asia. The Realia repertorium was most probably commenced soon after the year 1700. Originally it included only a limited number of subjects. During the eighteenth century, some subjects were discontinued, while others were added. The list expanded and around 1800 the realia books covered more then 2,000 subjects all together.

The subjects were defined in the General Secretary’s office. With reference to a subject list, the most important decisions on a certain subject were selected from the marginalia lists in the Resolution Books. Just as the Daily Journals, the Resolution Books have marginalia and at the beginning of a volume, a marginalia list. The person assigned to the selection of marginalia with the help of a subject list and the formulation of the realia, the realist, selected an estimated 10-15 per cent from the marginalia lists. The selected marginalia were written out in chronological order, according to the marginalia list. The realist sometimes added subjects to this chronological quire. The last step was to rearrange all the marginalia by subject, from A – Z. Moreover, the realist also checked the text of the resolution and formulated a longer, improved text. Hence, the realia may be considered improved marginalia. Now and then the annual collections of subject-arranged realia were compiled into a larger volumes. The compiled realia, often covering a number of years, survived in the archives of the Supreme Government and can be found in the intenvory (see 2169-2223).

The original realia were usually copied several times in the General Secretary of Batavia Castle for different users. The remaining 53 inventory numbers in ANRI contain a number of these original or copied Realia volumes. These can be read in the Digital Archive Collections. 

Apart from the Realia, the clerks at the General Secretary’s office created indexes of person’s names, the Personalia. Some 22 volumes (including copies) have survived (see 2224-2245). The Personalia were not published in the nineteenth century and are not included in the digitization project.

The 1882-1886 realia publication contains a compilation of an already incomplete 18th-century realia collection which was still available.Without careful comparative text analysis, it is hard to say which of the archival volumes were transcribed for the 1882-1886 publication. Some volumes which were used for transcription (an exercise which took 6 to 7 years) might now be lost.

Analyses of the realia show that most were created during the second half of the eighteenth century. During this period the Resolution Books expanded to an enormous size. The peak year of 1759 has a total of 1,578 realia to the resolutions of that particular year. As the graphic shows, although some years show a peak number of realia, the number of subjects remained fairly constant.

In 1743, the Supreme Government began to deliberate and record all matters concerning the other VOC factories in Asia and the outer posts in the Indonesian-Malay Region separately. These deliberations or ‘besognes’ were recorded in a seperate series, the Besogne Books. Realia after 1743 show references to the Besogne Books via ‘Bes.’, ‘b.’, or ‘bes.’. Some of the volumes show ‘R’ for ‘Resolutions’ and ‘B’ for ‘Besognes’, but not consistently. Unfortunately, the published realia are not always accurate in their references to the Besogne Books. The digital realia list references to the Resolution or Besognes in a separate column with ‘Resolutions’ and ‘Besognes’.

Another limitation of the the 1882-1886 realia publication is that it does not include folio page references. The reason is that many archival realia volumes do not have the folio page references, only the dates of the meetings of the Supreme Government. Consequently, the realia in this database are linked only to the dates of the meetings and not to specific folio pages. After clicking a realium, the system retrieves all scans of a particular meeting. The researcher has to search in the scans for a text passage related to a particular realium.

The realia publication of 1882-1886 did not provide a separate subject list. This database offers a separate subject list [2,050?] of subjects. This subject list clearly reflects the contemporary interest of VOC officials in certain subjects. Many subjects deal with such matters as the internal organization and logistics of the Company as a commercial enterprise. The aim of a subject repertorium was to maintain an overview of the Company decisions on a certain matter.

The digital realia not only offer a reconstruction of a contemporary entry, via the search functions it makes it possible to research many more topics from a present-day research perspective.

Continue to browse the Realia >>

The Realia to be quoted as: Hendrik E. Niemeijer and Yerry Wirawan, Realia to the General Resolutions of the Supreme Government of the Dutch East India Company (VOC) in Batavia, 1611-1805. A Digitized Eighteenth-century Subject Directory (Jakarta, Arsip Nasional Republik Indonesia/The Corts Foundation, 2013).

fields.description: The Daily Journals of Batavia Castle were created by the Secretary General of the Governor-General and the Council of Asia (together the High Government) in Batavia. These journals describe events of importance to record, copies of letters, references to resolutions, and much more. It reflects in great extent the detailed administration of the Dutch in Batavia. The Marginalia of the Daily Journals have been recorded and published on this website as a secondary entry in order to improve access to this archival series.
fields.title: Daily Journals
fields.description_id: Catatan Harian Kastil Batavia disimpan oleh Sekretaris Jenderal para Gubernur Jenderal dan oleh para Dewan Penasehat Asia (Pemerintah Agung) di Kastil Batavia.
fields.description_en: The Daily Journals of Batavia Castle were created by the Secretary General of the Governor-General and the Council of Asia (together the High Government) in Batavia. These journals describe events of importance to record, copies of letters, references to resolutions, and much more. It reflects in great extent the detailed administration of the Dutch in Batavia. The Marginalia of the Daily Journals have been recorded and published on this website as a secondary entry in order to improve access to this archival series.
fields.content:
Every day the clerk selected information from all the letters and oral reports forwarded to the Company central office. These covered general matters, the arrival and departure of European ships, the arrival and departure of Indonesian and Chinese ships, news from other Company establishments, news from the incoming letters from Bantam (West Java), Tanjungpura, Cirebon and other places on the North Coast of Java, letters to and from Asian kings, princes and local regents. The Daily Journals of Batavia Castle refer to thousands of incoming and outgoing letters. Hence, the Daily Journals are principally books in which letters and short letter summaries were registered and were not intended to be a written chronicle of all events in Batavia, as the title suggests.

The 165 volumes of Daily Journals from 1640 – 1806 cannot be accessed without a detailed secondary entry. As the image shows, every folio page of the originals has short text summaries written in the margins of the text. These short texts are called ‘marginalia’. At the end of a particular year, a clerk copied all the marginalia from every page. He listed them chronologically and added this marginalia list to the front pages of a volume for that year before it was bound. All of the marginalia lists from the Daily Journals have been entered into a database. Every single marginalium has been carefully compared with the marginalia on the specific folio pages. Through the entry of all marginalia into a database, researchers have detailed reference to almost every folio page.

The published Daily Journals of Batavia 1624 – 1682 were published between  1887 and 1931 in 31 volumes and are reproduced in the Retro book section.
fields.content_id:
Setiap hari sekretaris jenderal memilih informasi dari semua surat dan laporan lisan yang disampaikan ke kantor pusat Kumpeni. Yaitu mengenai urusan umum, ketibaan serta keberangkatan kapal-kapal Eropa, ketibaan serta keberangkatan kapal-kapal Indonesia dan Cina, berita dari kantor-kantor Kumpeni lain, berita dari surat-surat masuk dari Bantam (Jawa Barat), Tanjungpura, Cirebon dan sejumlah tempat lain di peseisir utara Jawa, surat-surat keluar dan masuk dari raja-raja Asia, para pangeran dan residen setempat. Catatan Harian Kastil Batavia merujuk kepada ribuan surat keluar dan masuk. Sebab itu, Catatan Harian merupakan buku-buku yang memuat surat-surat serta ringkasan-ringkasan surat yang dicatat tetapi tidak dimaksudkan untuk menjadi daftar tertulis mengenai semua peristiwa yang terjadi di Batavia, seperti yang mungkin tersirat dari judulnya.

Catan Harian dari 1640 – 1806, yang berjumlah 165 jilid tidak dapat diakses tanpa bantuan entri sekunder. Seperti yang nampak dalam gambar, di setiap halaman yang asli ada ringkasan pendek yang disebut ‘marginalia’. The akhir tahun, seorang kerani mengopi semua marginalia dari setiap halaman dan didaftar secara kronologis, dan daftar marginalia ini dibubuhkan pada halaman-halaman depan dari jilid untuk tahun bersangkutan sebelum dijilid menjadi buku. Semua daftar marginalia dari Catatan Harian sudah dimasukkan dalam sebuah pangkalan data. Setiap marginalium sudah dicocokan secara cermat dengan marginalia pada halaman-halaman folio bersangkutan. Dengan memasukkan semua marginalia ke dalam sebuah pangkalan data, maka para peneliti mempunya rujukan rinci ke hampir setiap halaman folio.

Catatan Harian Batavia (1624-1682) diterbitkan antara 1887 dan 1931 dalam 31 jilid dan direproduksi dalam Bagian Buku Retro.
fields.content_en:
Every day the clerk selected information from all the letters and oral reports forwarded to the Company central office. These covered general matters, the arrival and departure of European ships, the arrival and departure of Indonesian and Chinese ships, news from other Company establishments, news from the incoming letters from Bantam (West Java), Tanjungpura, Cirebon and other places on the North Coast of Java, letters to and from Asian kings, princes and local regents. The Daily Journals of Batavia Castle refer to thousands of incoming and outgoing letters. Hence, the Daily Journals are principally books in which letters and short letter summaries were registered and were not intended to be a written chronicle of all events in Batavia, as the title suggests.

The 165 volumes of Daily Journals from 1640 – 1806 cannot be accessed without a detailed secondary entry. As the image shows, every folio page of the originals has short text summaries written in the margins of the text. These short texts are called ‘marginalia’. At the end of a particular year, a clerk copied all the marginalia from every page. He listed them chronologically and added this marginalia list to the front pages of a volume for that year before it was bound. All of the marginalia lists from the Daily Journals have been entered into a database. Every single marginalium has been carefully compared with the marginalia on the specific folio pages. Through the entry of all marginalia into a database, researchers have detailed reference to almost every folio page.

The published Daily Journals of Batavia 1624 – 1682 were published between  1887 and 1931 in 31 volumes and are reproduced in the Retro book section.

fields.description: The National Archives of the Republic of Indonesia in Jakarta and the National Archives of the Netherlands have jointly identified and catalogued large sections of the 2,500 metres of VOC archives in the ANRI repositories.
fields.title: Inventories
fields.description_id: Arsip Nasional Republik Indonesia di Jakarta bersama dengan Arsip Nasional Belanda telah mengidentifikasi serta membuat katalog dari sejumlah besar arsip VOC sepanjang 2.500 meter lari yang tersimpan di ANRI.
fields.description_en: The National Archives of the Republic of Indonesia in Jakarta and the National Archives of the Netherlands have jointly identified and catalogued large sections of the 2,500 metres of VOC archives in the ANRI repositories.
fields.content:
The inventory has been published by Brill in Leiden in 2007. This inventory of the VOC archives is the leading inventory today and replaces the old inventory of 1882 by Van der Chijs of the The Bataviaasch Genootschap.

This current inventory, the Primary Finding Aid, is presented here and used as a reference today for the archival sources, the scanned archive folio, and secondary entries to archival series in particular.

The contents of the inventory is re-entered in the open source archival description tool ICA-AtoM. This tool is supported by the International Council of Archivists. The multilevel archival descriptions have been exported from this tool into the Encoded Archival Description data exchange format, in order to be published on this website.

The inventory is available in three languages:

  • Inventory in Indonesian
  • Inventory in English
  • Inventory in Dutch
fields.content_id: Penerbit Brill di Leiden di tahun 2007 menerbitkan daftar inventori baru yang merupakan Alat Bantu Penelusur Utama yang digunakan dalam situs ini untuk memperoleh pandangan tentang kerangka arsip VOC.

fields.description: This section gives direct access to the scans of the original 17th and 18th century handwritings of the VOC archive. The scanning has been started at ANRI in 2013 and will lead in time to a growing number of digital archival series. The first archive files presented here are part of the series of the Daily Journals.

fields.content: The first archival series that is now scanned were laminated and rebound during a restoration project in 1978 – 1981, initiated by the former Director of ANRI, Soemartini. She took the right decision to restore the series most important to historians first.
fields.content_id: Berkas-berkas arsip pertama yang sudah dipindai, telah dilaminasikan dan dijilid kembali dalam suatu proyek restorasi di tahun 1978-1981, yang diprakarsai oleh mantan Direktur ANRI, Soemartini (alm). Beliau telah mengambil keputusan benar dengan melestarikan terlebih dahulu seri-seri yang paling penting untuk para sejarawan.

fields.title: Home
fields.content: Arsip Nasional Republik Indonesia (ANRI) preserves 2.5 kilometres of Early-Modern Archives 1600-1800. Explore a selection of the main series online. Browse over 150,000 entries and discover thousands of references to persons and places, facts and events, and find what you need for your research.
fields.content_id: Arsip Nasional Republik Indonesia (ANRI) melestarikan 2,5 kilometer lari Arsip Masa Awal Modern 1600-1800. Silakan menelusur pilahan seri-seri utama secara on-line. Silakan pula menyelisik lebih dari 150.000 entri dan temukan ribuan rujukan terkair orang dan tempat, fakta serta peristiwa dan dapatkan apa yang anda perlukan untuk riset anda.

fields.description: The enormous amount of Marginalia entries can be searched in full text by entering one or more keywords. As some Marginalia has a vessel name, this also can be used as a selection criteria. To further decrease the number of results, it is possible to set a time frame. Selection can lead to one or more results. Each result can be clicked on, invoking the browse page on the exact position in the original Daily Journal.

fields.description: All ship names that are mentioned in the Marginalia are presented here. The ship names are grouped by their first letter and the number of Marginalia entries are counted. Each individual page per letter has the entries that start with that letter and each individual entry is also counted. Choosing a particular subject will start the Search Marginalia page and will invoke the selection immediately.

fields.longIntroText_en:
Kingdoms like Majapahit, Aceh, Melaka, Banten and Mataram rose and declined. During this period Malay emerged as the most important language of trade and religion (Islam), commencing with the Sultanate of Melaka. The 18th century, which might be said to begin somewhat earlier at the end of ‘Age of Commerce’ around 1680, is regarded as a separate historical category. Historical developments reveal their own specific characteristics.

Priangan in West Java began the production of coffee and hence became closely connected to the World market. Central Java experienced a number of wars of succession and conflicts about territory and power. In its efforts to control the ports of Java’s North coast, the Company became deeply embroiled in the various struggles for hegemony in Java. Java was the exception to the rule among the regions of the Malay-Indonesian world. Many other regions, Johor and Siak, the dozens of tiny kingdoms in Sulawesi, Bali, or the East Javanese kingdom of Balambangan among them, remained fairly autonomous throughout the 18th century. Although traditional power centres like Ternate and Makassar had fallen into the hands of the VOC, this did not mean that the Dutch controlled the whole of Sulawesi and Maluku.

Old peripheries emerged as new centres. Buginese, Mandarese and Makasarese maritime traders expanded their own networks and settlements along the coasts of Kalimantan, Riau-Johor and Sulawesi. A lively exchange of goods, ideas and culture took place across the borderless Melaka Straits, the Sunda Shelf and Java Sea. This ‘long’ but above all complex 18th century can be said to have ended on 1 January 1800, when the VOC was wound up and the East Indies (Indonesia) officially passed into the hands of the Netherlands government. After 1800, particularly when Governor-General Herman Willem Daendels entered the scene in 1808, Dutch – Javanese relations changed fundamentally. Almost nothing has survived of the inter-insular communication by letter between rulers, traders, spiritual leaders and others.

Official histories or court classics such as the Javanese Babad Tanah Jawi (History of the Land of Java) and Malay hikayat are first and foremost literary and cultural (genealogical) manuscripts. The VOC archive offers more accurate information about certain facts and events. Unquestionably its chief limitation is the one-sided contemporaneous European selection of facts and observation of events, inevitably affected by the specific interests of the writers of such documents. The challenge is to analyse these documents in the context of non-Western developments from a regional, non-European perspective. The Daily Journals of Batavia Castle also include hundreds of letters of local origin, carried around by special couriers operating in an advanced and efficient exchange-of -information network.

fields.shortIntroText_id: Antara 1450 dan 1700, daerah Kepulauan Asia Tenggara ini juga lazim disebut sebagai “ Kawasan di bawah Angin”, menyaksikan kemunculan Negara-negara Islam, diawali di kota-kota pelabuhan seperti Kesultanan Demak di Jawa, Aceh di Sumatra dan Melaka di Semenanjung Melayu. Kurun waktu itu juga disebut “Era Perdagangan” oleh karena keterkaitan kawasan ini dengan perdagangan maritim global.
fields.shortIntroText_en: Between 1450 and 1700 this part of Island Southeast Asia, also called “the Lands below the Winds”, experienced the rise of Islamic States, commencing in port towns and early Sultanates like Demak in Java, Aceh in Sumatra and Melaka on the Malay Peninsula. This period is also called “the Age of Commerce”, owing to the  connection of the region to a global maritime trade.
fields.shortIntroText: Between 1450 and 1700 this part of Island Southeast Asia, also called “the Lands below the Winds”, experienced the rise of Islamic States, commencing in port towns and early Sultanates like Demak in Java, Aceh in Sumatra and Melaka on the Malay Peninsula. fields.longIntroText_en: Arab, Armenian, Indian and other traders linked the Spice Islands up to the trading system of the Old World. On the Eastern side, Chinese and other traders around the South China Sea likewise contributed to the exchange of produce, the migration of peoples end exchange of ideas, culture and technologies. In the 16th century, the Portuguese and other Europeans established links between the traditional medieval Asian interactions and the rest of the world: the First Global Era. Via the Cape of Good Hope (founded in 1652 by Jan van Riebeeck), Asian goods were transported to Europe, but there was not much Europe could offer in return except cash and weapons. Throughout the history of Southeast Asia, its specific geographical conditions including coastlines, river systems and connecting seas have encouraged people to migrate and travel, trade and exchange, expand and contract. The the 17th- and 18th-century archives of the VOC were created in that world in flux. In part, they bear witness to the traditional flow of goods and migration of people, for example, the traditional export of Coromandel textiles and Bengal opium to Sumatra and Java. From the perspective of being able to place the Malay-Indonesian Archipelago at the strategic centre of [South and Eastern] Asia, the Harta Karun collection will expand.

fields.shortIntroText_id: Angin musim yang bertiup di Laut Cina Selatan mengembangkan layar sejumlah besar kapal jung yang berangkat dari pantai Jepang dan Cina, mengarah ke sejumlah pelabuhan di Asia Tenggara. Di sisi lain kawasan Maritim Asia, angin senantiasa bertiup di Samudra Hindia dari kawasan Laut Arab hingga ke Teluk Bengala serta mendorong banyak interaksi antara dunia Arab-Muslim, Persia dan India dengan sejumlah kerajaan di Asia Tenggara. Berbagai laporan serta surat ketika tiba di Kastel Batavia, membawa berita tentang perkembangan politik dan kegiatan ekonomi di kawasan Asia yang membentang luas.
fields.shortIntroText_en: The monsoon winds blowing over the South China Sea billowed the sails of many junks departing from the shores of Japan and China with a course set for Southeast Asian ports. On the other side of Maritime Asia, the prevailing Indian Ocean wind systems blowing over the region from the Arabian Sea to the Gulf of Bengal favoured the multitude of interactions which took place between the Arab-Muslim world, Persia and India and the Southeast Asian kingdoms. Reports and letters covering political developments and economic activities in the wide Asian region reached Batavia Castle.

fields.longIntroText_en: The Malay-Indonesian Archipelago and Asia at large were inescapably connected to global developments. The documents selected in these categories throw more light on the organization and logistics of the VOC as a European trading company, alongside other such companies. They illustrate its operations in Asian waters, its settlements and (pre)occupations, its role in the Intra-Asian trading world, its use of European military and shipping technology.
fields.name: Asian European interaction
fields.longIntroText: The Malay-Indonesian Archipelago and Asia at large were inescapably connected to global developments. The documents selected in these categories throw more light on the organization and logistics of the VOC as a European trading company, alongside other such companies. They illustrate its operations in Asian waters, its settlements and (pre)occupations, its role in the Intra-Asian trading world, its use of European military and shipping technology.
fields.shortIntroText_id: Dari abad 16 hingga 18, sejumlah perusahaan dagang Eropa masuk ke dalam kancah Asia, mencari rempah-rempah yang termasyhur (di Maluku), sutra Cina, lada dan tekstil India, emas Persia dan emas lantakan Jepang. Sejarah interaksi Asia-Eropa sangat rumit dan bersegi banyak. Bagian ini meninjau segi positif dan negatifnya. Menjelajahi hubungan dan kawasan baru, mengembangkan ilmu (bahasa, sejarah alam, geografi), alih teknologi serta hubungan diplomatik – semuanya penting untuk mengejawantahkan semangat globalisasi. Perjalanan serta penemuan penuh petualangan yang terjadi ketika itu masih tidak dapat diserap imajinasi. Akan tetapi, derasnya arus masuk kapal-kapal Eropa di perairan Asia, penaklukan dan pendudukan yang disusul dengan gelombang peperangan dan konflik, semuanya menunjukkan sisi gelap masa ini. Dokumen-dokumen yang terpilih seringkali menunjukkan kompleksitas peristiwa, ditinjau dalam kerangka waktu mereka sendiri yang terbatas.
fields.shortIntroText_en: From the 16th to the 18th century, European trading companies entered the Asian scene in search for the famed spices (in the Moluccas), Chinese silk, Indian pepper and textiles, Persian gold and Japanese bullion. The history of Asian-European interaction is complex and multi-facetted. This section examines both the positive and the negative sides. Exploring new contacts and lands, the development of science (languages, natural history, geography), the transfer of technology and diplomatic relations were all important expressions of globalization. Heroic voyages and discoveries still beggar the imagination. But the violent eruptions of European ships in Asian waters, the conquests and occupations and subsequent wars and conflicts reveal the downside. The documents selected often show the complexity of these events in their own limited time context.

fields.longIntroText_en: BATAVIA recalled the name of a legendary, heroic Dutch tribe, the ‘Batavieren’, famous for their struggle for freedom, who lived along the coast of Holland at the time of the Roman Empire. On the 12th, all the citizens and soldiers were summoned to the square in front of the warehouse by the beating of drums and the ringing of two bells,. After the official inauguration accompanied by the firing of cannon, the officers attended a banquet at which they drank from silver goblets, while the commoners were offered small cups of brandywine to celebrate. The inauguration of a new name did not change the fact that visiting Asian skippers in particular continued to use the old name, ‘Sunda Kelapa’. The Islamic rulers preferred the name ‘Jayakarta’, since Sunda Kelapa (formerly part of the Sundanese kingdom of Pajajaran) had been conquered by Muslim Demak in 1527. Early Dutch sources often read ‘Jaccatra’, and continue to use this spelling after its conquest by the VOC on 30 May 1619. The archives of Old Batavia are well preserved. Those of the Orphan Chamber (which includes the probate court), Notaries, College of Aldermen (the city court) all go back to the early 17th century. Although Batavia was the most important and largest colonial city in Asia at that time (Portuguese Goa and Spanish Manila were two other large colonial cities), research into the city’s history on the basis of primary archival sources has largely been neglected. One of the reasons has been a lack of interest in such an explicitly colonial topic after Indonesian independence. What do the archives offer? First and foremost information about a number of well-explored topics such as the functioning of the city boards, the publication of regulations (‘Plakkaten’) and the history of some of the remaining buildings such as the town hall (1710) and the ‘Portuguese’ church (1696). However, the main challenge for this website is to demonstrate that the daily social life, the ups-and-downs of small entrepreneurship and inter-ethnic and multi-cultural community life can still be reconstructed in some detail. The history of Batavia has invariably been connected to the social lives of the Company elite, but has barely brushed the daily reality of the lives of the more than 90 % of the Asian inhabitants in and around the city. In particular, the ‘Ommelanden’ or Environs offer a rich field of study. Many present-day names, as among them, Kuningan, Kalibata(s), Lebak Bulus, Pondok Gedé already appear in the 17th-century books kept by the District Council which supervised the maintenance of infrastructure and registration of landed properties and estates. Kampong life, water management, paddy and sugar cultivation, land ownership, slave labour, and the intermarriage of people of diverse ethnic backgrounds are emerging as favourite topics in the revision of Batavian history, to say nothing of the origins of the orang Betawi. The Harta Karun collection is to give priority to the selection of such documents, revealing more about the Asian and Indo (mestizo) citizenry of Batavia, their whereabouts and social life, giving the city back part of its forgotten Asian character.
fields.name: Batavia City and its Environs
fields.longIntroText: BATAVIA recalled the name of a legendary, heroic Dutch tribe, the ‘Batavieren’, famous for their struggle for freedom, who lived along the coast of Holland at the time of the Roman Empire. On the 12th, all the citizens and soldiers were summoned to the square in front of the warehouse by the beating of drums and the ringing of two bells,. After the official inauguration accompanied by the firing of cannon, the officers attended a banquet at which they drank from silver goblets, while the commoners were offered small cups of brandywine to celebrate. The inauguration of a new name did not change the fact that visiting Asian skippers in particular continued to use the old name, ‘Sunda Kelapa’. The Islamic rulers preferred the name ‘Jayakarta’, since Sunda Kelapa (formerly part of the Sundanese kingdom of Pajajaran) had been conquered by Muslim Demak in 1527. Early Dutch sources often read ‘Jaccatra’, and continue to use this spelling after its conquest by the VOC on 30 May 1619. The archives of Old Batavia are well preserved. Those of the Orphan Chamber (which includes the probate court), Notaries, College of Aldermen (the city court) all go back to the early 17th century. Although Batavia was the most important and largest colonial city in Asia at that time (Portuguese Goa and Spanish Manila were two other large colonial cities), research into the city’s history on the basis of primary archival sources has largely been neglected. One of the reasons has been a lack of interest in such an explicitly colonial topic after Indonesian independence. What do the archives offer? First and foremost information about a number of well-explored topics such as the functioning of the city boards, the publication of regulations (‘Plakkaten’) and the history of some of the remaining buildings such as the town hall (1710) and the ‘Portuguese’ church (1696). However, the main challenge for this website is to demonstrate that the daily social life, the ups-and-downs of small entrepreneurship and inter-ethnic and multi-cultural community life can still be reconstructed in some detail. The history of Batavia has invariably been connected to the social lives of the Company elite, but has barely brushed the daily reality of the lives of the more than 90 % of the Asian inhabitants in and around the city. In particular, the ‘Ommelanden’ or Environs offer a rich field of study. Many present-day names, as among them, Kuningan, Kalibata(s), Lebak Bulus, Pondok Gedé already appear in the 17th-century books kept by the District Council which supervised the maintenance of infrastructure and registration of landed properties and estates. Kampong life, water management, paddy and sugar cultivation, land ownership, slave labour, and the intermarriage of people of diverse ethnic backgrounds are emerging as favourite topics in the revision of Batavian history, to say nothing of the origins of the orang Betawi. The Harta Karun collection is to give priority to the selection of such documents, revealing more about the Asian and Indo (mestizo) citizenry of Batavia, their whereabouts and social life, giving the city back part of its forgotten Asian character.
fields.shortIntroText_id: Pelabuhan Sunda Kelapa yang kecil merupakan satu di antara enam pelabuhan kecil yang menjadi tempat pengiriman barang-barang asing ke kawasan hulu sungai di kerajaan lama Sunda di Jawa Barat. Khawatir terhadap semakin meluasnya pengaruh Portugis, pemimpin Muslim di Demak, Fatahillah menaklukkan pelabuhan ini di tahun 1527 dan memberinya nama Jayakarta. Sebagai pengunjung lama (sejak 1596) di pelabuhan Banten yang terletak di dekatnya , orang Belanda membangun sebuah loji dan gudang di Jayakarta di tahun 1610. Sesudah bertengkar dengan penguasa stempat terkait pembangunan sebuah kubu pertahanan dari batu, dan demi untuk memotong kemajuan pesaing Inggris, maka Gubernur Jenderal Jan Pietersz. Coen memutuskan untuk menaklukkan pelabuhan tersebut di tahun 1619 dan memberinya nama Batavia, demi menghormati kaum Jerman tertentu yang bebas dan merdeka, yaitu Batavieren yang di masa lampau menduduki delta sungai Rhine yang kini merupakan Negeri Belanda.
fields.shortIntroText_en: The small port of Sunda Kelapa was one of the six or so small ports from which foreign products were sent upstream to the old Sundanese kingdoms in West Java. Afraid of encroaching Portuguese influence, the Muslim chief of Demak, Fatahillah, conquered this port in 1527 and renamed it Jayakarta. Visitors to the nearby port of Banten since 1596, the Dutch built a lodge and warehouse in Jayakarta in 1610. After causing trouble with the local ruler about the construction of a stone stronghold, and to steal a march on English competitors, Governor-General Jan Pietersz. Coen decided to conquer the port in 1619. It was renamed Batavia, a reference to the legendary, free and independent German (Dutch) tribes, the Batavi, who occupied the Rhine Delta, modern Netherlands, in ancient times.

fields.longIntroText_en: War vessels like the Lancaran, Ghurab (Arabo-Persian) and Ghali (a galley that could be 150 feet long) tell us about the influence from the Ottoman Empires naval technology, in particular on Aceh. Nusantara’s traditional ports and trading networks became more and more subject to European maritime trading activities and naval dominion by heavily armed, large round ships. Increasing Chinese shipping after 1684 also influenced the trading patterns. Many traditional maritime features and activities continued, while others simply transformed. This section brings us in contact with ships, cargoes, crews, voyages, mualim and nakhoda, and syahbandars and laksamana.
fields.name: I.1 The Maritime World
fields.longIntroText: War vessels like the Lancaran, Ghurab (Arabo-Persian) and Ghali (a galley that could be 150 feet long) tell us about the influence from the Ottoman Empires naval technology, in particular on Aceh. fields.shortIntroText_id: Dalam banyak dokumen arsip tercermin Dunia Bahari yang dihuni masyarakat dari kawasan pesisir Jawa dan Madura, Bali, Melayu, Bugis dan kelompok etnis lain yang semuanya mengembangkan sayap kekuasaan mereka di perairan Nusantara ketika itu. Berbagai jenis kapal lalu-lalang mengembara ke aneka pelabuhan seperti ‘sampan’, ‘pencalang’, ‘gonting’ dan ‘paduakan’; mereka turut merambah jejaring perdagangan yang sudah terbentang sejak dahulu kala.
fields.shortIntroText_en: The Maritime World of the Coastal Javanese and Madurese, Balinese, Malay, Buginese and others dominating the seas of traditional Nusantara is reflected in many archival documents. Different boat types such as the sampan, pencalang, gonting and paduakan ventured out of different ports to participate in the old trading networks.
fields.shortIntroText: The Maritime World of the Coastal Javanese and Madurese, Balinese, Malay, Buginese and others dominating the seas of traditional Nusantara is reflected in many archival documents. Different boat types such as the sampan, pencalang, gonting and paduakan ventured out of different ports to participate in the old trading networks.
fields.longIntroText_id:
Ada juga berbagai jenis kapal perang seperti ‘lancaran, ghurab’ (dari Arab-Persia) dan ‘ghali’ (semacam galiun yang dapat berukuran hingga panjang 150 kaki); semua jenis kapal itu menuturkan kepada kita tentang pengaruh teknologi kelautan Kerajaan Ottoman, khususnya di Aceh.
Kemudian, kota-kota pelabuhan dan jejaring perdagangan tradisional Nusantara itu semakin mundur akibat kegiatan perdagangan maritim bangsa-bangsa Eropa dan semakin berpengaruhnya angkatan laut mereka yang menggunakan kapal-kapal besar bersenjatakan berat seperti challop yang rajin berpatroli di Selat Sunda dan Melaka. Semakin meningkatnya kegiatan pelayaran kapal-kapal Cina sesudah 1684 juga berimbas pada pola-pola perdagangan maritim dan tehnik pengangkutan barang dan manusia. Banyak pola serta kegiatan maritim Asia tradisional tetap bertahan sementara sejumlah lain bertransformasi. Bagian ini menghantar kita kepada kegiatan pelayaran Asia, muatannya, anak buah kapalnya serta penjelajahannya. Kami menelusur siapa dan apa saja kegiatan para mualim dan nakhoda, serta para syahbandar dan laksamana kala itu.

fields.longIntroText_en:
Less known are the Asian travellers who were far better acquainted with the islands and inner regions than the Europeans. Their reports are still being discovered in the archives. Published earlier are the lengthy report of Thomas Dias, a Portuguese-speaking citizen of Melaka, who visited the Mingangkabau capital of Pagar Ruyung (Central Sumatra) in 1684; the brief report of a Chinese trader who lived among the Batak for ten years before he went back to Batavia in 1701.
The secretary who kept the Daily Journals of Batavia Castle sometimes inserted the reports of individuals who had returned from an interesting journey. An example is the report by Sergeant Cornelis Bogaerd who went searching for bird’s nests in the steep hills of Kelapa Nungal in the Batavian hinterland. Another is the report on Aceh by the crew of the yacht den Dageraad in 1689. The Daily Journals also frequently mention the ‘honourless’ Captain Jacob de Roy who escaped troublesome Batavia and his local enemies in October 1691, only to return in 1698. His lengthy, adventurous account, published in 1698 and even translated into English, is highly informative about two independent port towns: Aceh and Banjermasin.
fields.name: I.2 Lands, Islands, Travels and Maps

fields.shortIntroText_id: Abel Tasman, William Dampier, Jacob Weyland, Jacob Roggeveen, James Cook dan sejumlah perantau dan juru mudi Eropa terkenal lain semuanya meninggalkan jejak mereka dalam arsip-arsip di Kastel Batavia. Nama beberapa kapal penjelajah terkenal seperti kapal layar Geelvink sering muncul dalam Catatan Harian. Kapal tersebut telah mengunjungi pesisir barat Australia di awal 1697.
fields.shortIntroText_en: Abel Tasman, William Dampier, Jacob Weyland, Jacob Roggeveen, James Cook and other famous European travellers and navigators all left their traces in the archives of Batavia Castle. Some famous exploration ships such as the yacht the Geelvink appear frequently in the Daily Journals. This ship visited the western coast of Australia at the beginning of 1697.
fields.shortIntroText: Abel Tasman, William Dampier, Jacob Weyland, Jacob Roggeveen, James Cook and other famous European travellers and navigators all left their traces in the archives of Batavia Castle. Some famous exploration ships such as the yacht the Geelvink appear frequently in the Daily Journals. This ship visited the western coast of Australia at the beginning of 1697.
fields.name_id: I.2 Negeri, Pulau Perjalanan dan Peta
fields.name_en: I.2 Lands, Islands, Travels and Maps
fields.longIntroText_id:
Yang kurang dikenal adalah para musafir Asia yang lebih mengenal pulau-pulau serta kawasan pedalaman dibandingkan dengan orang Eropa. Laporan mereka masih bermunculan dan ditemukan dalam arsip. Seperti yang telah diterbitkan lebih awal yaitu laporan Thomas Dias, seorang warga Melaka yang fasih berbahasa Portugis; tahun 1684 yang bersangkutan berkunjung ke ibukota Minangkabau, Pagar Ruyung di Sumatra Tengah dan ada pula laporan singkat seorang pedagang Cina yang bermukim di tanah Batak selama sepuluh tahun sebelum akhirnya pulang ke Batavia di tahun 1701.
Terkadang, sekretaris yang menyimpan Catatan Harian Kastel Batavia menyisipkan laporan pribadi dari mereka yang kembali sesudah melakukan perjalanan yang menarik. Salah sebuah contoh adalah laporan Sersan Cornelis Bogaerd yang melakukan perjalanan mencari sarang burung walet di bukit-bukit terjal Kelapa Nungal di kawasan pedalaman Batavia. Laporan menarik lain adalah yang dibuat awak kapal layar den Dageraad yang berarti ‘fajar’ di tahun 1689. Dalam Catatan Harian juga sering disebutkan tentang Kapten Jacob de Roy yang ‘tidak terhormat’; yang bersangkutan berhasil meloloskan diri dari Batavia yang penuh kesusahan dan musuh-musuh setempatnya di bulan Oktober 1691, tetapi kembali ke kota tersebut di tahun 1698. Catatannya yang panjang lebar dan penuh petualangan itu diterbitkan di tahun 1698 dan bahkan diterjemahkan dalam bahasa Inggris serta sarat informasi penting tentang dua kota pelabuhan mandiri yaitu Aceh dan Banjarmasin.

fields.longIntroText_en:
This interaction was lively during the ‘Age of Commerce’ but undoubtedly slowed down under the constraints of eighteenth- and nineteenth-century imperialism and growing colonial control. It was in the interests of a colonial power to restrict the movements and interactions of people in order to control them better.

The VOC archives are a rich source about inter-ethnic trading activities. Traces of ethnic identity and social organization are in these sources for the finding. One example is the cacah soma or lists of households in the Priangan region of West Java; that from 1686 is the oldest we know of. The Daily Journals of Batavia Castle frequently give lists of Priangan chiefs which help to reconstruct Sundanese identity. Other ethnicities like the Javanese, Madurese, Balinese and Buginese are easy to trace in the city archives of Batavia. Immigrants like the Hindu-Indians (‘gentiven’) or Muslim-Indians (‘moors’), and the Chinese also left thousands of traces, for instance, in the form of requests and small-scale trading contracts. All the fragments of information should help our analyses and lead to the creation of a better historical understanding of multi-ethnic societies and how they once functioned.
fields.name: I.3 Peoples, Groups, Ethnicities and Social Organization
fields.longIntroText:
