fields.transcription:
Conferentie over Sukadana

Dagregister 1699

ANRI (VOC, Hoge Regering, 2519, fols. 262-)

23 April 1699

[262] Heeden voor de middagh is door de gecommitteerde heeren den directeur generael Joan van Hoorn, en den raed ordinaris Dirk de Haes in de ordinary vergadersale van haer Edele de Hoge Regeringe, met den Pangerang Natta Diradja, den Ratoe Bagus Seminingrat en nogh vier van de voornaamste haer in rang volgende, de hoofden over de alhier aangecome vaertuygen en volckeren van den Sulthan van Bantam tot de expeditie na Succadana, nader gesproken wegens eenige principale poincten van deselve expeditie, sooals bij de onderstaande insertie van de gehoude aantekeninge deswegen te lesen is, luydende van woorde tot woorde aldus:

Donderdag 23 April 1699 ’s morgens.

Den Pangerangh Natta Diradja en Ratoe [fol. 263] Bagus Semi Ningrat nevens de Aria’s Natta Sedana, Ksoema Dilaga, Astra Diradja, Niti Sedana met den Sabandhaer Van de Voorde, voor de gecommitteerde heeren Joan van Hoorn en Dirk de Haes ter vergadersale verschenen en geseten sijnde, is hen eerst voorgehouden dat dewijle sij hier nu met de vaertuygen en magt des Sulthans van Bantam aangekomen waeren omme nevens die van de Compagnie na Succadana te gaan, haer Ed. gaarne soude van haer verstaan hoedanig de meyninge des Sulthans lagh, om het werk aldaer te beginnen, waerop de Pangeran Natta Deradja na eenige onderlinge samenspraek met Semi Ningrat antwoorde dat de konink sulx t’eenemael aan haer Ed. goedvinden hadde gedefereert en haer aanbevolen sig daer na te rigten en sulx volkomentlijk op te volgen.

Waerop andermael gerepliceert sijnde dat sulx wel waer was maer dat men uyt des koninx brieven niet anders als in ’t generael desselfs versoek om ’s Compagnies adsistentie tot uytvoeringe van sijn voornemen tegen die van Succadana gesien hebbende, wij wel gaarne wilden weten of hij niet nader dienthalven van den koningh was geïnstrueert hoedanigh de saeken aldaer souden dienen aangevangen, behandelt en vervolgt te werden, nademael het des Coninx sake was, en dese regeringe geresolveert hadde oversulx sijn mayesteyts intentie daeromtrent na vermogen te helpen uytvoeren en seconderen en daerom gaaren wisten off men die van Succadana ten eersten met de wapenen souw aantasten, dan wel alvorens door eenige afgesondene des koninx gevange volkeren soude reclameren [fol. 264] ende verdere nodige satisfactie van haer vorderen.

Waerop Nata Diradja antwoorde dat het feyt en ongelijk door die van Succadana den Sultan van Bantam aangedaan, ons bekent was en klaer bleek daerover sij satisfactie en straffe hadde versogt te nemen, en dat sij de maniere daeromtrent aan haer Ed. hadde gelaten als die beter wisten en ervaren waren, hoedanig omtrent diergelijcke gelegentheden behoorde gehandelt te werden, als sij en haren konink die nogh jongh en onervaren was, en noyt nogh geen oorlogssaken hadde bij der hand gehad, en oversulx als een soon aan sijn vader dies behandelinge en uytvoeringe aan ons goetvinden en oordeel had gedefereert en overgegeven.

Op ’twelke dan aan gemelte Pangeran wederom gedient sijnde, dat de Javaanse en Hollandse methode in sodanige gelegentheden, dikwils verscheyde waren en dat het onder ons off de Europianen in gebruyk was, ymant van een ander beledigt sijnde, men alvorens door afgesondene van de sodanige satisfactie quame te vorderen, in sulker voegen als men oordeelde te behoren alvorens tot de wapenen te komen, en dat dan de sodanige satisfactie gevende en vergiffenisse versoekende men sonder gewelt tot een bemiddeling konde geraken en des neen dan tot de wapenen quam te treden.

Waerop Natta Diradja weder betuygde sulx sodanig te behoren en billik te wesen en ook met des coninx intentie overeen te sullen komen, en op ’t daarbij geallegeerde off het dan ook niet nodig soude sijn, sij op ’t spoedigste den Sulthan nader adviseren en sijn ordre en goetvinden terwijl sij nogh hier waren quamen te versoeken, soo scheen hij in ’t [fol. 265] eerst daerin te acquiseeren maar sig een weynigh bedagt en met Semi Ningrat in ’t Javaens gesproken hebbende, verklaerde hij sigh nader sulx niet van noden te oordeelen en maer tijd met over en weder schrijven door te sullen verlopen, nadien hij van den Koningh ten vollen gequalificeert was onder belofte en versekeringe van desselfs aggreatie over haer verrigte om te doen en uyt te voeren ’tgeen door dese regeringe hem mogte werden aanbevolen, en ook te helpen beraden, op en over hetgeene haer Edelens mogte goetvinden met hem te overleggen.

Waerna vervolgens iets gesproken en haer voorgehouden sijnde, bijaldien die van Succadana nu met de wapenen aangetast werdende off wel voor off op haer aankomst mogten de vlugt nemen, hoedanig men dan verder souw behoren te procederen, soo seyde hij dat men deselve dan moeste sien te vervolgen, maar omtrent des ook gevraegt wesende van Banjer, dewijl daeraf in de Bantamse brieven van ’t opperhoft ook gewaegt wert, soo seyde Natta Diradja dat Banjer te verre van daer en geheel aan ’t oost en Succadana aan ’t west eynde van Borneo gelegen lagh, maer dat men daer sijnde na onderlinge bevindingen en overleg, en den toestand der Succadaners eerst souw komen te resolveren, hoedanig deselve in cas van wapenen te vervolgen en vooral die van Landak in ruste en onder den Sultan van Bantam te herstellen souden sijn. Wanneer hem segt wiert onse Europeën over de moerassen en bergen niet konde marcheeren, dat hij toestemde en seyde men konde dan van onse Inlanders en alleen een hooftofficier off sergeant van d’onse bij haer voegen. En tot besluyt dat men die van Succadana in allen gevalle soo verre diende te brengen om haer te dwingen aan de stranden te moeten [fols. 266] blijven wonen, en dat ten dien eynde, daer elders ter bequamster plaets vooreerst een post van den koningh en Compagnies volkeren, in manschap gereguleert na den toestand en magt den Succadaners soude dienen te verblijven. En wijders dat hij versogt haer Edelens ordre maer ten spoedigsten mogten werden vervaerdigt en dat hij maer wenschte hoe eer hoe liever te mogen van hier de reys aannemen.
fields.title_nl: Conferentie in het Kasteel van Batavia met gezanten van Banten over de voorgenomen militaire expeditie naar Sukadana, 23 april 1699
fields.translation_id:
Konperensi mengenai Sukadana

Catatan Harian (Dagregister) 1699

ANRI (VOC, Hoge Regering, 2519, fols. 262-)

23 April 1699

[262] Hari ini menjelang siang, di ruang rapat kantor Pemerintah Agung, para tuan penguasa direktur jenderal Joan van Hoorn dan anggota dewan Dirk de Haes mengadakan pertemuan untuk membincangkan beberapa hal penting terkait ekspedisi ke Sukadana. Pertemuan diadakan dengan Pangerang Natta Diradja, Ratu Bagus Seminingrat dan empat rekan mereka serta para mualim kapal yang telah tiba di sini dan beberapa tokoh masyarakat penduduk kesultanan Banten; mereka semuanya duduk sesuai tingkat jabatan masing-masing. Butir-butir pembahasan dalam rapat dapat dibaca dalam catatan berikut ini.

Kamis, 23 April 1699 pagi.

Pangeran Natta Diradja dan Ratoe [fol. 263] Bagus Semi Ningrat bersama dengan Aria Natta Sedanana, Ksoema Dilaga, Astra Diradja, Nti Sedana dan Syahbandar Van de Voorde menghadap para tuan penguasa Joan van Hoorn dan Dirk de Haes dan duduk di ruang rapat; selanjutnya mereka mengatakan bahwa maksud kedatangan mereka di sini bersama kapal mereka masing-masing beserta pasukan Sultan Banten adalah untuk bergabung bersama dengan kapal-kapal Kumpeni akan pergi berlayar ke Sukadana. Para Tuan Yang Mulia ingin mengetahui bagaimana Sultan berencana akan melaksanakan tugas tersebut di sana, yang kemudian dijawab oleh Pangeran Natta Deradja, sesudah berunding sebentar dengan Semi Ningrat, bahwa raja menyetujui rencana para Tuan Yan Mulia dan telah memerintahkan mereka untuk turut melaksanakan rencana tersebut.

Kemudian sekali lagi dijawab bahwa kendati apa yang dikatakan itu benar adanya, namun dalam surat-surat paduka raja hanya tercantum permohonan bantuan dari Kumpeni untuk melawan Sukadana, dan sebab itu kami ingin mengetahui apakah raja tidak memberitahukan atau memerintahkan bagaimana operasi di sana akan dimulai, dilaksanakan dan dilanjutkan mengingat semua itu adalah urusan Raja, dan bahwa pemerintahan ini telah memutuskan untuk membantu dan memberi dukungan sesuai kemampuan agar maksud tujuan paduka tercapai, dan oleh karena itu kami ingin diberitahukan apakah musuh di Sukadana akan diserang, ataukah utusan raja akan terlebih dahulu berusaha untuk membebaskan sejumlah rakyat yang disandera di sana dan kemudian meminta [fol. 264] penguasa di sana memenuhi sejumlah tuntutan. 

Menanggapi pertanyaan tersebut, Nata Diradja menjawab bahwa berbagai kesalahan yang sudah dilakukan oleh penguasa Sukadana terhadap Sultan Banten sudah kita semua maklum dan sudah menjadi kenyataan, dan sebab itu mereka perlu dihukum, dan bahwa bagaimana hal itu akan dilaksanakan diserahkan kepada Yang Mulia karena lebih memahami dan berpengalaman bagaimana hal-hal demikian sebaiknya ditangani, sementara mereka dan raja mereka masih muda dan belum berpengalaman, dan belum pernah terlibat langsung dalam peperangan, dan karena itu sebagaimana seorang putra memercayakan kepada ayahandanya, maka kami menyerahkan perihal ini sepenuhnya kepada kebijakan dan keputusan Kumpeni perihal cara penanganan dan pelaksanaan rencana tersebut.

Kemudian sekali lagi dikatakan kepada Pangeran tersebut bahwa cara-cara yang biasa dipakai orang Jawa dan orang Belanda dalam menangani perihal tersebut seringkali berbeda dan bahwa untuk kami atau orang Eropa, apabila seseorang telah menghina orang lain, maka terlebih dahulu akan dikirim utusan untuk menuntut penyelesaian sesuai cara yang sepatutnya, sebelum mengangkat senjata, dan dengan demikian maka dapat diadakan perundingan dengan pihak bersangkutan dan mencapai penyelesaian dan permintaan maaf tanpa melakukan kekerasan dan tanpa menggunakan senjata.

Kemudian Natta Diradja kembali berkata bahwa demikianlah yang seharusnya dan layak dilakukan yaitu sesuai dengan maksud raja, dan [ditanyakan] apakah dianggap perlu atau tidak untuk terlebih dahulu merundingkan dengan Sultan perihal ini dan mendapat persetujuan beliau sementara mereka sekarang sudah ada di sini untuk menyampakan permohonan, maka pada awalnya yang bersangkutan [fol. 285] nampaknya setuju untuk melaksanakannya, akan tetapi kemudian berubah pikiran dan sesudah berunding dengan Semi Ningrat dalam bahasa Jawa yang bersangkutan menyatakan bahwa hal itu tidak perlu dilakukan dan bahwa melakukan surat-menyurat perihal itu hanya akan makan waktu, dan bahwa yang bersangkutan sudah diberi kuasa sepenuhnya oleh Raja dan sudah berjanji akan melaksanakan apa yang dianjurkan oleh pemerintah di sini, dan juga untuk merundingkan hal-hal yang dianggap perlu oleh para Yang Mulia.

Kemudian dibicarakan dan ditunjukkan kepada mereka langkah-langkah apa yang akan diambil, apabila orang-orang Sukadana akan melarikan diri setelah dihadapi dengan senjata, maka dikatakan mereka harus berusaha mengejarnya, namun terkait dengan Banjar yang juga ditanyakan, dikatakan bahwa masih ditunggu surat dari pedagang kepala di Banten dan sebab itu Natta Diradja mengatakan bahwa Banjar terletak terlalu jauh di sebelah timur sementara Sukadana terletak di sebelah barat pulau Borneo, akan tetapi apabila mereka sudah berada di tempat dan sesudah merundingkan dan melihat apa yang terjadi di tempat, maka soal Sukadana akan diselesaikan dengan mengedapnkan perundingan dan apabila harus mengadakan pengejaran dengan memakai senjata maka tujuannya adalah untuk menciptakan keamanan dan ketenangan di Landak dan menempatkannya kembali di bawah kekuasaan Sultan Banten. Ketika kepada yang bersangkutan dikatakan bahwa serdadu Eropa kami tidak dapat berjalan melalui rawa-rawa dan pegunungan, maka yang bersangkutan menyetujui kalau digunakan serdadu-serdadu pribumi dan hanya dipimpin oleh seorang perwira kepala atau seorang sersan dari kumpeni. Akhirnya diputuskan bahwa mereka semua akan diangkut ke Sukadana untuk memaksa orang di sana untuk bermukim di tepi pantai [fols 266] dan agar maksud itu dapat dicapai maka terlebih dahulu harus dibangun di tempat yang paling baik sebuah pos yang merupakan tempat perwakilan raja dan Kumpeni dan dijaga serta dikelola oleh tentara, dan sesuai keadaan dan kekuatan, dan kemudian rakyat Sukadana harus bermukim di tempat tersebut. Yang bersangkutan kemudian mohon agar perintah para Yang Mulia dapat dilaksanakan secepatnya, dan yang bersangkutan ingin diperbolehkan mulai melakukan perjalanan tersebut secepat mungkin.
fields.short_title_id: Konperensi di Kastil Batavia dengan para utusan dari Banten mengenai rencana ekspedisi militer ke Sukadana, 23 April 1699
fields.translation_en:
Conference about Sukadana

                                                            Daghregister  1699

 

 

23 April 1699

 

[262] Today in the fore noon, in the accustomed assembly chamber of the Honourable Supreme Government, the gentlemen delegated [for this task], Director-General Joan van Hoorn and Councillor-in-Ordinary Dirk de Haes, held more detailed discussions about the expedition to Sukadana with Pangeran Natta Diradja, Ratoe Bagus Seminingrat plus another four of their confreres next to them in rank, the captains of the fleet and in the army of the Sultan of Banten which have arrived here. The reason was [to hammer out] a few outstanding points about this expedition, as can be read in the minutes kept enclosed below, which state verbatim as follows:

 

Thursday 23 April 1699 morning.

 

Pangeran Natta Diradja, Ratoe [fol. 263] Bagus Seminingrat and Aria Natta Sedana, Ksuma Dilaga, Astra Diradja and Niti Sedana as well as Syahbandar Van de Voorde, presented themselves in the assembly chamber before the gentlemen delegated [to receive them]. After they were seated, the first [matter] raised was that now that the vessels and army of the Sultan of Banten had arrived here to join those of the Company to proceed to Sukadana, the Honourable [Company] would be pleased to hear from them how the Sultan’s forces proposed to conduct the action there. After some consultation with Seminingrat, Pangeran Nata Diradja replied that the king deferred absolutely to the judgement of the Honourable Company and had advised them to be guided by this and follow it to the letter.

 

The reply to this was that, whereas this was indeed true in general terms, in view of the fact that the King’s letters contained just the same request for Company help to pursue his campaign against Sukadana, what we really wanted to know was whether he had received further instructions from the King about this how the campaign there should be launched, conducted and pursued. Furthermore, although it was the King’s affair, this government had resolved to assist and second His Majesty’s plan as much as it could. Hence, it was anxious to know whether the first step would be to make an armed attack on Sukadana, or should it begin by attempting to liberate some  the sovereign’s captured people [being held] there [fol. 264] as well as making some other demands for reparations.

 

Natta Deradja answered that as we were aware of the injustice perpetrated against the Sultan of Banten by [his fellow Sultan] of Sukadana, that without beating about the bush, he demanded satisfaction be sought and punishment be meted out but that the manner in which should be accomplished was in the hands of the Honourable Company as it was more conversant with and more experienced in how dealing with such a situation, whereas they and their King, who was but young and inexperienced, had never engaged in warfare. Therefore, in this situation, they deferred and submitted as a son to his father to our course of action and judgement in its process and execution.

 

Hereupon the said Pangeran was informed that the way in which the Javanese and the Dutch dealt with such situations often differed and that among Europeans it was the custom that, if one person had been insulted by another, envoys were sent to seek reparation. This was what was expected to take place before any resort to arms and that were the demands to be satisfied and amnesty sought, it was possible to negotiate without any recourse to violence and arms.

 

Whereupon Natta Diradja again affirmed that the matter should and must be pursued in accordance with the King’s strategy and, in conjunction with this, [he asked], even though this was what they had come here to request, whether it was necessary to advise the Sultan of this as speedily as possible in order to obtain his orders and approbation. Initially [fol. 265] he seemed to think that this course should be pursued but, having thought it over a moment and consulting with Semidiningrat in Javanese, he declared that he thought that this would not be necessary as such correspondence back and forth would just waste time, and that he had plenipotentiary power from the King, with the promise and assurance of the approbation of the same for whatever he did in assenting to and executing whatever this government might advise, and also for weighing up whatever Their Excellencies might think to confer with him.

 

Afterwards there was some discussion in which the question was posed: How they would proceed if an armed assault was launched on Sukadana and the people took flight before the army arrived? He replied that the same plan should be adhered to, but when a similar question was asked about Banjar, as letters to this effect were still awaited from the chief merchant in Banten, Natadiraja replied that Banjar lay too faraway, right on the eastern coast of Borneo, whereas Sukadana was situated on the west coast, and that, after they had arrived there, they would attempt to resolve the situation in Sukadana first through mutual discussions and consultations. If indeed the choice were to be made for armed intervention, the prime purpose of this would be to restore law and order under the Sultan of Banten in Landak. When he was informed that our European [soldiers] would not be up to marching through the swamps and over the mountains, he understood and said that we needed only dispatch our Native troops under just one of our commanding officers or sergeants. In conclusion, it was agreed that all should be transported at least as far a Sukadana to force [fol. 266] [the people there] to continue to reside on the coast. If this were to be accomplished, the first [step should be] to find the most suitable spot there [to set up] a post for the troops of the king and the Company organized in their formal ranks, so that they could monitor the situation in and [keep an eye on] the power of Sukadana. He also requested that the orders of the Honourable Company be carried out as quickly as possible and that he wished to undertake the expedition at the first possible opportunity.
fields.short_title: Conference in Batavia Castle with the diplomats from Banten concerning the planned military expedition to Sukadana, 23 April 1699
fields.short_title_en: Conference in Batavia Castle with the diplomats from Banten concerning the planned military expedition to Sukadana, 23 April 1699

fields.introduction:
Geelvinck

 

‘Around one o’clock in the afternoon, we anchored at the roadstead of Batavia, with five fathoms depth. God be praised for a save journey’. These lines were written by captain Willem de Vlamingh on March 20 1697 at the end of his journal which he had kept during his expedition to the Southland (Australia). On the same day a clerk in Batavia reported the arrival of De Vlamingh, as we can read in the following document.

This meant the final act of an expedition of three ships that had started eleven months before, in May 1696. After long deliberations the VOC-directors in the Netherlands had decided to organize this voyage. Three goals were pointed out. In the first place the ships had to look for a VOC-ship, De Ridderschap van Holland, that had departed from Flushing in 1693. It had reached Capetown and had continued its voyage to Batavia from there, but since then nothing had been heard of the ship. So, although this had happened three years before, not all hope had gone of finding De Ridderschap van Holland and her crew. Maybe it had stranded somewhere in the Indian Ocean on the shores of the islands Amsterdam or St Paul, or on the westcoast of Australia. Nevertheless, before investigating these places De Vlamingh was ordered to sail to the Tristan da Cunha-islands in the southern Atlantic.

All these islands and coasts had to be surveyed thoroughly, described and mapped out. A report was expected on commercial opportunities for the Company. Besides that, the expedition had a scientific aspect. On request of the Amsterdam VOC-director, the scholar Nicolaas Witsen, De Vlamingh and his men should try to catch one or more inhabitants of Australia and transport them to Batavia or even to the Netherlands. They could possibly provide useful information on land and culture. Witsen also urged to add a painter to the crew.

After well organized preparations De Vlamingh started his voyage with the frigate Geelvinck and two smaller ships, the Nijptang en Het Wezeltje. All together 198 man were boarded, including the painter Victor Victorsz.

The expedition started successfully. Tristan da Cunha was reached and inspected. From there the ships sailed for Capetown where three persons from Asia were taken aboard. The Vlamingh expected them to serve as translators in Australia. The islands Amsterdam and St. Paul were surveyed and after that during almost two months, Australia’s westcoast was investigated and mapped. And although they stuck on some remnants of Dutch ships, they found no tracks of De Ridderschap van Holland or its crew.  From Australia the ships sailed to Batavia.

The goal of the expedition had been reached only in a limited way. The lost ship was not found, and although De Vlamingh could give full reports of the geographical and physical aspects of the places he had inspected, on flora, fauna and the inhabitants, the directors were disappointed that he had not investigated largers parts of the Southland. De Vlamingh’s conclusion was that Australia was in no way useful for the Company. In this wild, dry and desolate land no minerals were found and commercial relations with the inhabitants could be in no way profitable. After reporting extensively De Vlamingh returned to the Netherlands. His voyage was the last VOC-expedition of any importance.

This expedition is extremely well documented. All instructions have been preserved in the VOC-archives in The Hague, the names of the crewmembers are all known, journals of the three ships have survived as well as the maps and the watercolours of Victor Victorsz. These last are kept in the Maritiem Museum Rotterdam.

 

The whole expedition is extensively analyzed in G.G. Schilder: De ontdekkingsreis van Willem Hesselsz. De Vlamingh in de jaren 1696-1697 (Den Haag 1976)
fields.transcription:
Ontdekkingstocht de Geelvink

20 Maart 1697; Arrivement van ’t freguat de Geelvink alhier ter rhede; kort verhael van de principale voorvallen in desselfs reyse na ’t Zuytland, fols. 231-234.

 

Tegens middag arriveerde uyt de havenen onses lieven vaderlands alhier ter rheede het frequat de Geelvink, ten eynde onder den 17e deser vermeld benevens de hoeker de Nijptangh, en ’t galjoot het Weseltje voor de kamer Amsterdam in zee gelopen, den 3e may van ’t voorleden jaer 1696 onder het gesag van den schipper Willem de Vlamingh en den adsistent Joannes Bremer, voorts bemant met 101 zeevarenden en 33 militairen, aangaande welke reyse en wat ten principalen gedurende deselve van aanmerkinge is comen voor te vallen, uyt ’t gehoude journael van den voormelte schipper De Vlamingh cortelijck alhier werd genoteert, dat se den 17e augusty daeraan volgende gearriveert waren aan de eylandenv an Tristan d’Acinha, leggende op de hooghte van 37 graden 14 minuten verdeelt in verscheyde eylanden ontrent een mijle meer en minder van malcanderen, dat men de twee grootste door de sterke brandinge in hebbende konnen aandoen, alleen maer aan eene der kleynste te lande was geweest, sijnde bewassen met halm of lang gras, voorsien van goet drinkwater en veel peguwyn vogels mitsgaders de zee daer omtrent seer visrijk ’t welk nae hun meyninge alleen waart was in de somer die eylanden aan te doen alsoo sulckx alsdan met minder gevaer en met meerder gemak dan in de voorschreve tijd soude konnen geschieden, hebbende nu aldaer swaare kouw en ruw weer moeten uytstaan, sijnde voorts den 21e ditto daer vandaan vertrocken, ende den 7 september aan Cabo de Goede Hoop verscheenen, mitsgaders den 27e october van daer geseylt.

 

Inmiddens soo daer te lande, als op andere schepen overgegaan zijnde 6 zeevarende, en 1 militairen, dog daerentegen weder bekomen hebbende 5 zeevarende, 1 militairen en 3 inlanders, de laestgemelde om aan ’t Suytland bij ontmoetinge van menschen omtrent de spraek te passe te komen. Dat men verders den 29e november de eylanden St. Paulo en Amsterdam gelegen op 38 gr. 31 minuten Z. breete belopen het laeste omgeseylt mitsgaders aan het eerstgemelte soo bequamen rhee off ankerplaets gevonden had als aan Cabo de Goede Hoop in de Tafelbaay, dat dese eylanden veel bosschagie en boomen voortbraghte van de dikte van een man om de middel, en dat men er oversulx een seer groot getal scheepen met branthoud soude connen gerieven, ook had men op hetselve niet alleen gevonden verscheyde spruyten vers water, maer ook een waterwel uyt de gront opkomende soo heet dat men vissen in andere niet verre van daer gelegene binnenwateren ofte poelen gevangen sijnde, daerin gaar hadde konnen kooken.

 

Dat men den 5en december wijders van daer vertrocken was nae het Suytlant, en hetselve den 29en dito op de hoogte van 31 gr. en onderentusschen soo naauwkeurigh doorsoght en bekruypt had, als mogelijck was geweest, hebbende hun eerste leghplaets aldaer begrepen aan het misteyland voorsien van veele wilde dogh riekende boomen en aan de vaste wal gevonden en met kleen vaartuygh ten eynde toe opgevaren een revier wel 10 mijlen landwaert in streckende, maer daerontrent niet van aanmerkinge vernomen, dan een oude plank gelijkende voor d’nast?? van de verdubbelingh van een schip te wesen, en verre op ’t land twee swarte menschen ook eenige seer kleene hutjes met riet overdekt dogh vervallen en daer niemant in was, buytendien had men de kust al langs stevenende na de gelegentheyt presenteerde, verscheyde malen te lande geweest, 5 a 6 mijlen weegs gemarcheert en hier en daer wel eenige vuuren ontmoet, maer ook al niemant daerontrent, dogh op de hooghte van 28 graden 10 minuten waren aan strant gesien 10 swarte menschen van gemeene stature, geheel naekt, en sonder geweer, maer door de branding belet sijnde daer aan lant te komen, had men haer niet konnen begaan, behalven dat se oock seer schuw ten eersten wegh gelopen waren, hebbende voorts aldaer op de hooghte van 25 graden 37 minuten gelegen op Dirk Hertogsrheede, een seer bequame plaets voor schepen om te anckeren, en daer aan land op een heuvel ofte hoogte gevonden een neer- ofte omgevalle paal, met een tinne schootel volgens hetgeen er op gegraveerd stond, door de overheden van ’t schip den Eendraght in hunne uytreyse na dese gewesten in den jare 1616 aldaer opgeregt; sijnde in plaetse van deselve die men herwaerts heeft gebragt aldaer in gelijker voegen weer gestelt een andere tinne schotel met het vereyste opschrift en notitie ten belange van gem. schip den Eendraght en de voyagie van dese dry scheepjes, te weten de name derselve en dies overheeden, dien datum der aancomste en vertreck waer vandaan, en herwaerts heenen etc., wesende verders buytn ’tgeene verhaelt is aldaer ter kuste niet voornaems ontdekt, insonderheyt niet eenigh mensch, teeken of overblijfsel van het vermiste schip de Ridderschap.

 

’t Voornaemste oogmerk der heeren principalen ontrent dese besendinge, sijnde het land in sigh selfs, voor sooveel men had konnen bespeuren, woest, sandigh en van weynigh vruchtbaarheyt sijnde wel eenige gom en lakboomen gesien en monsters daervan medegebragt maer deselve van geen beduyden ofte waarde bevonden wesende geen ontdekt van seeker soort van bruyn gepluymde swanen, mitsgaders kasuarisse, en tijgers dogh de twee laeste maer bij presumptie uyt de poot-teekens gemerkt eygentlijk geene daervan sijn gesien.

 

Hebbende in het oversteken van ’t Zuydland op de hoogte van 21 graden nae ’t eyland Java den 21e february deses jaers nae ’tgene hiervoor reets is vermelt van 5e deser op 10 graden 57 minuten ontmoet het eyland Mony, ’twelk en passant aangedaan en beset bevonden weird met veelerley geboomte waeraff men oordeelde eenige bequaam om masten van gemaekt te connen werden nevens veel palmytboomen sonder evenwel ten belange van de eerste soort yets speciaels te noteren wegens hare hooghte, dikte, aart en eygenschappen van hout en ’tgene men om over haer bequaamheyt tot voorsz. gebruyk te oordelen alvoren soude behoren te weten.

 

Sijnde wijders op dit bodempje gedurende de reyse overleden 11 zeevaarende, sulx alhier nogh te lande brenght 89 zeevarende, 33 militairen en 3 inlanders ofte in alles 125 zielen.
fields.title_nl: Kort verhaal betreffende de reis van het fregat de Geelvink naar het Zuidland (Australië), 20 maart 1697
fields.translation_id:
Pelayaran Jelajah pergata ‘de Geelvink’

20 Maret 1697; Ketibaan pergata de Geelvink di dermaga setempat; catatan singkat seputar kejadian-kejadian penting selama pelayaran ke ‘Zuytland’ (benua Selatan), fol. 231-234.

 

Pada sore hari tiba di dermaga setempat, pergata de Geelvinck yang berangkat berlayar dari pelabuhan tanah air tercinta kami dan akhirnya tiba pada tanggal 17 seperti dilaporkan, bersama dengan kapal jenis hoeker de Nijptangh dan kapal barang het Weseltje (yang akhirnya pada tanggal 17 bulan ini bersama dengan de Nijptangh dan het Weseltje berangkat berlayar) dan pada tanggal 3 Mei tahun lalu 1696, di bawah pimpinan mualim Willem de Vlamingh dan wakil mualim Joannes Bremer bersama 101 awak kapal dan 33 serdadu; berikut diberikan ringkasan catatan terkait perjalanan tersebut serta kejadian-kejadian penting yang berlaku, seperti dilaporkan dalam buku harian yang ditulis oleh mualim De Vlamingh yaitu bahwa mereka tiba pada tanggal 17 Agustus di kepulauan Tristan d’Acinha yang terletak pada 37 derajat 14 menit dan terdiri dari beberapa pulau yang terpisah sekitar kurang lebih satu mil satu dari yang lain, bahwa oleh karena ada hempasan gelombang besar maka mereka hanya dapat mencapai pulau terkecil yang ditanami padang rumput panjang (ilalang), dan di pulau itu juga ditemukan air minum yang baik serta banyak burung pinguin, lagipula di laut sekitarnya terdapat banyak ikan dan menurut mereka pulau-pulau tersebut sebaiknya dikunjungi selama musim panas karena di waktu itu tidak terlalu banyak bahaya sehingga akan lebih mudah mencapai pulau-pulau tersebut dibandingkan dengan waktu sekarang ketika harus menghadapi suhu udara dingin dan angin kencang, dan kemudian pada tanggal 21 bulan itu mereka meninggalkan kepulauan itu dan tiba pada tanggal 7 September di Tanjung Harapan, dan berlayar meninggalkan Tanjung pada tanggal 27 Oktober.

 

Sementara itu, baik di daratan maupun di kapal ada 6 pelaut dan 1 serdadu yang pindah kapal tetapi ada juga pendatang baru yaitu 5 pelaut, 1 serdadu dan 3 pribumi, yang terakhir ini bertugas sebagai penerjemah apabila nanti di Suytland bertemu dengan penduduk setempat. Kemudian dilaporkan bahwa pada tanggal 29 November mereka mencapai pulau-pulau St. Paulo dan Amsterdam yang terletak pada 38 derajat dan 31 menit Garis Lintang Selatan dan mereka berlayar mengitari pulau yang tersebut belakangan itu lagipula di pulau yang disebut pertama ditemukan tempat membuan sauh yang sama baiknya seperti di Teluk Meja (Tafelbaay) di Tanjung Harapan, di kedua pulau tersebut terdapat banyak hutan dengan berbagai pepohonan  yang kelilingnya sama seperti keliling perut seorang dewasa sehingga mereka akan dapat memasok kayu bakar kepada banyak kapal, dan di pulau itu mereka tidak hanya menemukan beberapa kali kecil dengan air segar tetapi juga sebuah sumur yang airnya demikian panasnya sehingga dapat dipakai untuk memasak ikan-ikan yang ditangkap di sungai-sungai atau empang hingga matang.

 

Kemudian dilaporkan bahwa pada tanggal 5 Desember mereka meninggalkan tempat itu dan berlayar menuju Suytlant yang dicapai pada tanggal 29 bulan sama dan pulau itu terletak pada 31 derajat dan segala sudut di pulau itu sudah dijelajahi dengan seseksama mungkin dan mereka mendirikan tempat beristirahat mereka yang pertama di pulau yang berkabut itu di mana terdapat banyak pepohonan liar yang mengeluarkan bau dan kemudian menemukan tempat berlabuh dan kemudian dengan menggunakan sebuah perahu kecil menyusur sungai sepanjang lebih dari 10 mil masuk ke dalam daratan, tetapi di sana hanya menjumpai sebuah papan tua yang menyerupai tiang layar bekas dari sebuah kapal yang dipakai sebagai dinding tambahan kapal, dan nun jauh di daratan mereka melihat dua orang berkulit hitam dan beberapa gubuk yang sangat kecil tanpa atap dan sudah rusak dan tidak berpenghuni, selain itu mereka sudah menelusuri pantai dan sejauh memungkinkan masuk ke pedalaman sejauh 5 hingga 6 mil dan di sana sini menjumpai bekas api unggun, tetapi tidak bertemu manusia. Akan tetapi pada lokasi 28 derajat 10 menit mereka melihat di pantai 10 orang hitam dengan tubuh berukuran sedang, telanjang bulat dan tanpa menyandang senjata akan tetapi karena terdapat gelombang kuat mereka tidak dapat mendarat, sehingga tidak dapat menjumpai orang-orang itu yang juga sangat malu dan berjalan pergi menjauh, dan kemudian pada 25 derajat 37 menit di lokasi Dirk Hertogsrheede mereka menemukan tempat sangat baik untuk kapal-kapal membuang sauh, dan di sebuah bukit atau pada suatu ketinggian ditemukan tergeletak sebuah tonggak bersama sebuah cawan timah dengan ukiran yang menyebutkan bahwa cawan berasal dari kapal Den Eendraght yang berlayar ke kawasan ini dalam tahun 1616 dan tonggak itu telah diangkut ke sini (ke Batavia) dan diletakkan bersama dengan sebuah cawan timah lain dengan pahatan bahwa cawan berasal dari kapal yang sama den Eendraght dan catatan tentang pelayaran dari tiga kapal kecil tersebut, termasuk nama-nama kapal, tanggal keberangkatan dan ketibaan dan dari mana dan berlayar ke mana, dsb., dan kecuali yang dikisahkan tadi maka di pantai itu tidak ditemukan hal-hal yang penting, dan juga tidak dijumpai seorang manusiapun atau pun sisa-sisa dari kapal yang hilang De Ridderschap.

 

 

Hal utama yang menarik bagi para tuan pimpinan seputar misi pelayaran ini adalah bahwa kawasan tersebut, sejauh dapat ditelusuri, sangat liar, berpasir dan tidak terlampau subur kendati kami melihat ada beberapa pohon karet dan getah perca dan kami mengambil contoh-contoh yang ternyata tidak berharga dan kami tidak menemukan angsa-angsa berbulu cokelat, atau pun burung kasuari dan harimau, dan keberadaan dua binatang tersebut terakhir itu hanya didasarkan pada kesimpulan yang ditarik dari jejak-jejak kaki sementara binatang itu sendiri tidak kami lihat.

 

 

Ketika menyeberang dari Zuydland ke pulau Jawa maka pada ketinggian 21 derajat kami menjumpai pada tanggal 21 Februari tahun ini, seperti yang telah dilaporkan, pulau Mony yang terletak pada 10 derajat 57 menit, yang kami lewati sepintas dan menemukan bahwa di pulau itu terdapat aneka macam pepohonan yang beberapa di antaranya menurut pandangan kami dapat dipergunakan untuk membuat tonggak layar, dan juga terdapat banyak pohon palem namun kami tidak membuat catatan khusus tentang pohon itu tentang tinggi, ketebalan serta sifat kayu pohon itu sehingga tidak dapat mengetahui apa kegunaan pohon itu.

 

Selanjutnya dikabarkan bahwa selama perjalanan ini telah meninggal 11 pelaut, dan yang berhasil mendarat kembali adalah 89 pelaut, 33 serdadu dan 3 orang pribumi, seluruhnya berjumlah 125 orang.
fields.short_title_id: Laporan singkat tentang pelayaran pergata de Geelvinck ke Negara Selatan (Australia), 20 Maret 1697
fields.translation_en:
Voyage of exploration of the Geelvink

20 March 1697; Arrival of the frigate the Geelvink in the local roads; brief account of the principal events on the voyage of the same to the Southland, fols 231-234.

 

Around midday on 17th of this month the frigate the Geelvink arrived here in the roads from our beloved fatherland. On 3 May of the previous year 1696,  she had set sail with the hooker the  Nijptangh and the galliot the Weseltje, under the auspices of  the Amsterdam Chamber, under the command of Commander Willem de Vlamingh and his second-in command/ First Mate Joannes Bremer, with a crew of 101 sailors and thirty-three soldiers. Noted here in brief are the principal events which came to pass on this voyage, from the log kept by the afore-said Commander De Vlamingh. On the following 17 August they arrived at the island group of Tristan de Cuñha, situated at 37 degrees 14 minutes South Latitude, composed of various islands separated from each other by approximately a mile of sea. They were unable reach the two largest because of the heavy surf but they did visit one of the smallest which was covered with long grass, supplied with good drinking water and many penguins. The sea there teems with fish, a reason which would make it worthwhile to visit the islands only in the summer as this would be less dangerous and could be done more easily than at the time  of their above-mentioned attempt, because they had to brave severe cold and rough weather. They left there on the 21st of the same month and appeared off the Cape of Good Hope on 7 September and sailed again from there on 27 October.

 

At that time, on land there from the other ships were six sailors and one soldier left the ships but those who joined were five sailors and one soldier and three natives, the last-mentioned could be useful as interpreters in meetings with people in the Southland. Then on 29 November they reached the islands of St Paul and Amsterdam situated at 38 degrees and 31 minutes South Latitude. They sailed past the last-mentioned but at the afore-mentioned there was a suitable roadstead or anchorage like that in Table Bay at the Cape of Good Hope. These islands are rich in shrubs and trees as thick as a man’s waist, which would make it possible to supply a great many ships with firewood. Also on these same islands it is possible to find various fresh water springs, not to mention a well of water surging up from the ground so hot that it is possible to cook fish caught in inland waters or pools properly in it.

 

They departed from there again on 5 December to sail for the Southland, and made landfall at 31 degrees on 29th of the same month. There they meticulously explored and investigated as far as this was possible and anchored first at Misteyland (Fog/Rottnest Island), mainly covered with trees growing wild but pleasantly scented. Reaching the mainland they sailed along a river in a small craft going at least 10 miles inland, but saw nothing of interest, other than an old plank, from the double inner skin of a ship’s hull, and in the far distance two black people and a few tiny huts covered with thatch, but ramshackle and unlived in. Then, while sailing along the coast whenever the opportunity presented itself, they landed and marched hither and thither 5 or 6 miles,  coming across some fires but nobody in the vicinity. However, at 25 degrees 10 minutes ten black people were seen on the beach. They were of medium build and stark naked and unarmed, but as the surf prevented any landing and they were unable to land there. Also they were extremely timid and fled away at the first opportunity. They then reached Dirk Hartog’s Roads (Cape Inscription on Dirk Hartog Island off Shark Bay) at 25 degrees 37 minutes, a very suitable harbour in which ships could anchor. When the landed they found on a hill or mound a fallen stake on which was a pewter plate, which according to what was engraved on it had been put

there by the officers of the ship the Eendraght on her outward- bound voyage in 1616. In the place of that one which they have brought here, they set up another pewter plate with an appropriate inscription and a note about the significance of the said ship the Eendragt and of the voyage of these three small vessels, to wit, their names and their officers, the dates of their arrival and departure. Furthermore, apart from those mentioned on the coast no apparent trace, in particular of people, signs or remains from the missing ship the Ridderschap, was found.

 

The main concern of the voyage dispatched by the men-in-charge was the country itself, which as far as could be discerned was deserted, sandy and not very fertile. Some resinous and lacquer-bearing trees were observed and samples of these were brought back, but were not found to be of any significance or value. A certain swan with brown plumage was discovered as were cassowaries and tigers. The latter two are only assumptions as only their pug marks were seen, not they themselves.

 

Having set course from the Southland to the island of Java at 21 degrees on 21 February this same year, after what is mentioned above, on 5 of this month, at 10 degrees 57 minutes they came across the island of Moni, where they put in and found that it was covered with forest. Some trees were judged suitable for masts. There were also plenty of palm trees, but [they are] not as important as the afore-mentioned sort, but notable for their height, thickness, nature and the characteristics of their wood, which should permit men to judge their suitability for future use.

 

During the voyage on this small vessel eleven sailors died, and hence eighty-nine crew members,  thirty-three soldiers and three natives, or 125 souls in all landed here.
fields.introduction_en:
Geelvinck

 

‘Around one o’clock in the afternoon, we anchored at the roadstead of Batavia, with five fathoms depth. God be praised for a save journey’. These lines were written by captain Willem de Vlamingh on March 20 1697 at the end of his journal which he had kept during his expedition to the Southland (Australia). On the same day a clerk in Batavia reported the arrival of De Vlamingh, as we can read in the following document.

This meant the final act of an expedition of three ships that had started eleven months before, in May 1696. After long deliberations the VOC-directors in the Netherlands had decided to organize this voyage. Three goals were pointed out. In the first place the ships had to look for a VOC-ship, De Ridderschap van Holland, that had departed from Flushing in 1693. It had reached Capetown and had continued its voyage to Batavia from there, but since then nothing had been heard of the ship. So, although this had happened three years before, not all hope had gone of finding De Ridderschap van Holland and her crew. Maybe it had stranded somewhere in the Indian Ocean on the shores of the islands Amsterdam or St Paul, or on the westcoast of Australia. Nevertheless, before investigating these places De Vlamingh was ordered to sail to the Tristan da Cunha-islands in the southern Atlantic.

All these islands and coasts had to be surveyed thoroughly, described and mapped out. A report was expected on commercial opportunities for the Company. Besides that, the expedition had a scientific aspect. On request of the Amsterdam VOC-director, the scholar Nicolaas Witsen, De Vlamingh and his men should try to catch one or more inhabitants of Australia and transport them to Batavia or even to the Netherlands. They could possibly provide useful information on land and culture. Witsen also urged to add a painter to the crew.

After well organized preparations De Vlamingh started his voyage with the frigate Geelvinck and two smaller ships, the Nijptang en Het Wezeltje. All together 198 man were boarded, including the painter Victor Victorsz.

The expedition started successfully. Tristan da Cunha was reached and inspected. From there the ships sailed for Capetown where three persons from Asia were taken aboard. The Vlamingh expected them to serve as translators in Australia. The islands Amsterdam and St. Paul were surveyed and after that during almost two months, Australia’s westcoast was investigated and mapped. And although they stuck on some remnants of Dutch ships, they found no tracks of De Ridderschap van Holland or its crew.  From Australia the ships sailed to Batavia.

The goal of the expedition had been reached only in a limited way. The lost ship was not found, and although De Vlamingh could give full reports of the geographical and physical aspects of the places he had inspected, on flora, fauna and the inhabitants, the directors were disappointed that he had not investigated largers parts of the Southland. De Vlamingh’s conclusion was that Australia was in no way useful for the Company. In this wild, dry and desolate land no minerals were found and commercial relations with the inhabitants could be in no way profitable. After reporting extensively De Vlamingh returned to the Netherlands. His voyage was the last VOC-expedition of any importance.

This expedition is extremely well documented. All instructions have been preserved in the VOC-archives in The Hague, the names of the crewmembers are all known, journals of the three ships have survived as well as the maps and the watercolours of Victor Victorsz. These last are kept in the Maritiem Museum Rotterdam.

 

The whole expedition is extensively analyzed in G.G. Schilder: De ontdekkingsreis van Willem Hesselsz. De Vlamingh in de jaren 1696-1697 (Den Haag 1976)
fields.introduction_id:
Geelvinck

 

‘Sekitar pukul satu siang kami membuang sauh di pangkalan laut Bataia yang kedalamannya lima depa; puji Tuhan pelayaran kami berlangsung dengan selamat.’ Demikian ditulis kapten Willem de Vlamingh pada tanggal 20 Maret 1697 di akhir catatan harian yang dibuatnya selama perjalanan ke Southland (Australia). Pada hari yang sama seorang kerani di Batavia melaporkan kedatangan De Vlamingh, seperti yang dapat kita baca dari dokumen berikut. Itulah akhir sebuah ekspedisi oleh tiga kapal yang memulai pelayaran mereka sebelas bulan sebelumnya., di bulan Mei 1696. Sesudah berunding panjang lebar, para direktur VOC di Negeri Belanda akhirnya memutuskan untuk melakukan pelayaran tersebut yang mempunyai tiga tujuan. Pertama, kapal-kapal itu harus mencari sebuah kapal VOC, De Ridderschap van Holland, yang berlayar dari Flushing di tahun 1693. Kapal itu telah mencapai Capetown dan kemudian melanjutkan pelayarannya ke Batavia, namun setelah itu tak ada kabar apa pun dari kapal tersebut. Oleh karena itu, kendati kejadian tersebut berlangsung tiga tahun sebelumnya, masih dikandung harapan untuk menemukan kapal tersebut bersama awaknya. Mungkin kapal itu kandas di suatu tempat di pantai kepulauan Amsterdam atau St. Paul di Samudera Hindia, atau di pantai barat Australia. Namun, sebelum menyelidiki lokasi-lokasi tersebut, De Vlamingh diperintahkan untuk berlayar dahulu ke kepulauan Tristan da Cunha, di bagian selatan samudera Arlantik.

 

Semua pulau dan pantai bersangkutan harus ditinjau secara cermat dan juga dipetakan. Diharapkan pula akan dapat dibuat sebuah laporan terkait dengan peluang komersial bagi Kumpeni. Di samping itu, ekspedisi tersebut juga dibebani tugas ilmiah. Atas permintaan direktur VOC dari Amsterdam, yaitu ilmuwan Nicolaas Witsen, De Vlamingh dan awaknya harus berusaha untuk menangkap satu atau beberapa orang penduduk Australia dan membawanya ke Batavia, atau bahkan ke Negeri Belanda. Orang-orang setempat itu mungkin saja dapat memberikan informasi berguna tentang kawasan serta kebudayaan setempat. Witsen juga mendesak agar seorang pelukis diikutsertakan sebagai awak kapal. Sesudah melakukan persiapan matang, De Vlaming memulai perjalanannya dengan menggunakan kapal pergata Geelvinck dan dua kapal lain yang lebih kecil yaitu Nijptang dan Het Wezeltje. Seluruh awak kapal berjumlah 198 orang, termasuk pelukis yang bernama Victor Victorsz.

 

Pada awal perjalanan semuanya berlangsung mulus. Mereka berhasil mencapai Tristan da Cunha dan mengamati serta menyelidikinya. Dari tempat itu, ketiga kapal kemudian berlayar menuju Capetown dan di tempat itu, tiga orang Asia diangkut dalam kapal. De Vlaming berharap orang-orang itu akan dapat bertindak sebagai penerjemah di Australia. Pulau Amsterdam dan juga St Paul ditelusuri dan sesudah itu, pantai barat Australia juga diselidiki selama dua bulan dan dipetakan. Kendati mereka menemukan sejumlah sisa sebuah kapal Belanda, mereka tidak menemukan petunjuk apa pun terkait kapal De Ridderschap van Holland atau awak kapalnya. Dari Australia mereka kemudian berlayar menuju Batavia.

 

Tujuan ekspedisi tersebut hanya tercapai sebagian. Kapal yang hilang tidak ditemukan, dan walaupun De Vlaming dapat memberikan laporan lengkap tentang keadaan geografis dan fisik kawasan-kawasan yang telah diselidikinya, juga tentang flora dan fauna serta penduduknya, para direktur kecewa bahwa kapten itu tidak menyelidiki berbagai kawasan lebih luas dari Southland. Kesimpulan De Vlamingh adalah bahwa Australia tidak berguna bagi Kumpeni, Di kawasan yang masih buas, kering serta terpencil itu tidak ditemukan sumber mineral, lagi pula tidak akan dapat dijalin hubungan perdagangan yang menguntungkan dengan penduduk setempat. Sesudah memberikan laporan panjang lebar, De Vlamingh kembali ke Negeri Belanda. Pelayarannya itu merupakan ekspedidi VOC terakhir yang ada nilainya.

 

Ekspedisi tersebut didokumentasikan dengan baik. Semua surat-surat perintah disimpan dalam arsip VOC di Den Haag, nama dari para awak kapal tercatat dengan rapih, catatan harian dari ketiga kapal tersebut masih ada, termasuk peta dan gambar-gambar dengan cat air yang dibuat Victor Victorsz. Peta dan gambar itu sekarang tersimpan di Museum Maritim di Rotterdam.

 

Sebuah analisa rinci tentang seluruh ekspedisi tersebut dapat dibaca dalam tulisan G.G. Schilder, De ontdekkingsreis van Willem Hesselsz. De Vlaming in de jaren 1696-1697 (Den Haag 1976)
fields.short_title: Short story concerning the journey of the frigat ‘De Geelvinck’ to the Southland (Australia), 20 March 1697

fields.citation: Timothy Barnard, “Thomas Dias’ travel to Central Sumatra in 1684”, in: HARTA KARUN: Hidden Treasures on Indonesian and Asian-European History from the VOC-archives in Jakarta, document 1, Jakarta: Arsip Nasional Republik Indonesia, 2013
fields.introduction:
‘Thomas Dias’s Account of his Journey to Central Sumatra in 1684’

How does one describe a society that is vastly different from your own, and one that is contained in a blank space on a map? In the seventeenth century, when the United East India Company (VOC) first ventured into the vast Indonesian Archipelago, this was a common problem. While the VOC was first and foremost a trading company, a business, the employees needed to understand the societies with which they hoped to interact. When Thomas Dias travelled to the polity of Minangkabau in 1684 he reflected the possibilities for exploration and understanding of new societies, and the tale reflects the richness of the VOC archival materials.

The VOC gained control over Malacca in 1641. Malacca was one of the key ports in the region, as it oversaw shipping between the South China Sea and the Indian Ocean, thus linking vast empires of goods, peoples and cultures. Malacca had been the centre of a Malay polity until 1511, when the Portuguese captured the port and ruled it until the arrival of the VOC. Assisting the VOC in the takeover of Malacca was the polity of Johor – where many of the Malay Malaccan elite had fled following 1511. Johor and the VOC remained allies after 1641, although tensions often arose as Johor began to exert control over the vast forested resources of eastern Sumatra over the next few decades.

Central Sumatra became a place of interest, and rivalry, for both Johor and the VOC following the discovery of tin mines at the headwaters of the Siak and Kampar Rivers in the 1670s. The region was a vast network of communities that traded goods between the interior and the Malacca Straits, whose leaders would pledge their allegiance to whichever state provided the most benefits. Beyond these riverine communities were the Minangkabau highlands, where a vibrant matrilineal society oversaw the production of rice and the harvesting of gold. Trade from these highlands, an almost mystical place in the early modern mind, flowed down the rivers to the Malacca Straits, making its origin a goal of any merchant in the region. Into this mixture of trade rivalries, cultural differences, and misunderstandings stepped Tomas Dias, who made a remarkable journey into the Minangkabau highlands and helped develop some of the early contacts between the VOC and states in the interior of Sumatra.

Very little is known about Tomas Dias. Beyond this account of his journey to Minangkabau in 1684, he appears occasionally in VOC records, which portray him as a trusted employee, often acting as a liaison with local rulers and traders. For example, in 1682 Dias delivered letters to the rulers of Indragiri and the 1680 census of Malacca records that Dias was married and had eight children and two slaves. Under the category for race, Dias is described as dark (zwarte).

Despite these glimpses into Tomas Dias’ life in Malacca, almost everything we know about him comes from a report he wrote on the 25 September 1684 describing his journey to Minangkabau. The origins of this journey lay in failed attempts among VOC officials to communicate with leaders of the tin mining areas in central Sumatra in 1683. Dias had been a member of an expedition to Patapahan in May 1683 under the leadership of Hendrik Temmer. The expedition accomplished little, but Dias remained in Patapahan after the others left, setting up a small trade post as a representative (morador) of the Company. While in this position, Dias fell afoul of a Dutch representative, Hendrik van Roonhuijzen, who visited Patapahan later in the year. Van Roonhuijzen believed that many of the continuing trade problems in the region were due to Dias’ incompetence. Dias eventually was able to defend himself before the Melaka authorities, but his position and trustworthiness as a middleman had been brought into question. To re-establish his position with VOC officials Dias made a bold proposal that would mark him in the archives, and thus history: since the Minangkabau ruler could possibly provide some order to this volatile region Dias would travel to the Minangkabau capital and secure support for VOC trade interests in the region. VOC officials approved the idea. In May 1684 Tomas Dias sent a letter to the Minangkabau ruler in Pagar Ruyung (‘Paggar Oejom’ in the document) requesting approval for a visit, which received a positive reply shortly thereafter. Dias quickly assembled all of the necessary equipment, and, along with 37 other people, began a journey into the Minangkabau highlands, which he describes in this document.

In the report that Dias submitted in June 1684 he describes the various villages, and difficulties, he encountered between eastern Sumatra and the Minangkabau highlands. Dias left from the main stapling post of Patapahan and the VOC party continually encountered uncooperative leaders, eventually forcing them to travel into the highlands via the Kampar Kiri and the spiderweb of paths that connected the various rivers. While Dias emphasizes the difficulties in his journey in the report, it also clear that he was constantly negotiating among various parties with regard to trade and diplomatic alliances. After several weeks of travel, the party reached a village near the Minangkabau capital of Pagar Ruyung. This location is most likely not where the location of the modern village of Pagar Ruyung, as it shifted due to internal rivalries in subsequent centuries.

The Minangkabau ruler sent a Raja Malijo (“Raja Melayu”, who may have been an official that dealt with trade to the east, or Malay lands) with 500 men to accompany Dias into the capital in the late afternoon. The next morning Dias entered the capital and an audience took place. According to Dias, the king’s two sons met him at the edge of the royal district with 4000 men and royal umbrellas unfurled. They were to escort the outsiders to meet the ruler. After a formal presentation of gifts and a letter from Malacca Governor Cornelis van Qualbarg, Dias was invited inside the palace, where he presented the ruler with paraphernalia related to betel chewing and then took part in polite diplomatic discussion concerning his journey. Among the topics discussed were the perils of Dias’ journey and the fact that he was probably the first Christian to enter Minangkabau.

A few days later the Minangkabau ruler invited Dias, to whom he gave the honorary title “Orang Kaya Saudagar Raja”, to open a Dutch post in Patapahan and to help him gain control over the trade flowing on the Siak and Indragiri Rivers. When Dias mentioned that Johor controlled Siak, the Minangkabau ruler simply replied that the area, “from Pulau Gontong up to Patapahan is mine.”

After receiving these various honours, Dias then began to prepare for his return journey. When he was about to leave, he was presented with various letters and seals to prove that he made the journey, and possessed the authority now bestowed upon him, as well as a box full of “improper pictures”, which apparently had come as a present from a Dutch official who had sent them to the Minangkabau ruler. Dias then left Pagar Ruyung and proceeded to travel along the usual trade routes. Raja Malijo accompanied the group, and along with 3000 men, until they reached the stapling post of Siluka, from where Dias floated down the Kampar Kiri and then moved overland, reaching Patapahan in July 1684.

Very little was accomplished with the journey, however. A representative of the Johor sultan wrote to Malacca in 1684 warning that the Siak River was Johor territory and off limits to Dutch traders. Although Patapahan had remained loyal to the authority of Minangkabau, Johor made great efforts to bring other upstream villages into its sphere of influence. By the time Dias returned from his trip in August 1684, Johor already had gained some control over the Kampar Kanan through agreements with leaders of the various trading posts. Although the VOC quickly opened a lodge in Patapahan, it was eventually abandoned due to attacks and the decision of local traders to funnel their tin and gold through villages on the Kampar River.

Dias’ report of his journey to Minangkabau gained a small measure of fame in the late nineteenth century when a Dutch civil servant, F. De Haan, brought attention to its existence in a published account that appeared in the Tijdschrift voor Indische Taal-, Land- en Volkenkunde in 1897. Since then, Dias has appeared in at least four other major accounts of the region, including F. M. Schnitger’s Forgotten Kingdoms of Sumatra, as well as works by Christine Dobbin (Islamic Revivalism in a Changing Peasant Economy), Leonard Andaya (The Kingdom of Johor) and Jane Drakard (A Kingdom of Words). Historians have often used this account as a rare opportunity to glance the workings of the Minangkabau court in the early modern period as well as the vibrant trade and diplomacy of upstream Sumatra in the late seventeenth century. Thus, while it is an account that depicts an epic journey that brought little benefit to the VOC, it does allow later scholars an opportunity to better understand the complex relationships between various communities in central Sumatra in the late seventeenth century.
